column151: for example. While those who rarely dine out or get take-out will likely fare better with a card that offers elevated rewards on groceries rather than dining.'
column152: 'Many credit cards offer perks and benefits beyond the ability to earn rewards. Premium travel cards may offer exclusive airport lounge access
column153: free checked baggage and airline incidental credits. Many cards on the market offer other perks like extended warranty protections and other travel protections and insurances. Even cards without an annual fee may offer several money-saving benefits.'
column154: 'Cards aimed at helping you shore up your credit profile
column156: work by reporting your on-time payment behavior to the credit bureaus so that over time
column157: your score can improve with a record of positive payment history. There are many cards on the market aimed at those seeking to boost their profile. The best ones charge little to no annual fee and don’t carry account opening or other unnecessary fees. There are some unsecured cards available too
column158: although these tend to be unavailable to those with a recent bankruptcy.'
column159: 'Credit cards provide everything from consumer protections to valuable benefits and substantial earnings potential
column160: but only when used correctly. Here’s how to get the most value out of your cards.'
column161: 'Earning any type of rewards is better than nothing
column162: but to get the most out of your credit card
column163: you’ll want to ensure you’re earning the most rewards you can on the types of purchases you make most often. Balancing this with a type of rewards you value and are easy to redeem–cash back
column165: 'Most credit cards come with additional benefits
column168: store credits and discounts or travel perks. Whenever you get a new card
column169: or come up on your card’s renewal anniversary
column170: familiarize yourself with its current benefits to make sure you know what benefits you’re entitled to or which ones you may need to enroll for.'
column171: 'Credit cards are a convenience but if you’re not making payments toward your balance due
column172: you’re likely racking up hefty fees. Be sure to make minimum payments on time every month to avoid late fees. Ideally
column173: pay off your full balance to avoid interest charges as well. Not only will you save on fees
column174: but you’ll keep your credit in good standing for future card and loan approvals at advantageous rates.'
column175: 'Different types of credit card users will benefit most from different types of credit cards.\xa0 Here are some tips to help you decide what’s best for you.'
column176: 'Value Shoppers will likely benefit most from cash back cards that provide rewards on everyday purchases. These cardholders will want to minimize annual fees and aren’t concerned about travel rewards or high end perks. Check out the best cards for shopping and best cards for groceries to learn more.'
column177: 'The best credit card for travelers will vary based on the kind of traveler you are.\xa0 If you like to play license plate ABC
column178: check out our best cards for road trips. If you prefer your travels at 35
column180: check out the best airline credit cards.'
column181: 'When you’re just starting out it can feel like a Catch-22. You need good credit to get a credit card
column182: but you need a credit card to build good credit. Fortunately there are some cards out there that are good for both those starting out and those needing to get back on track.\xa0 Check our best first credit cards and best cards for rebuilding credit lists to learn more.'
column183: 'College students have a plethora of credit card options because the banks understand the value of a lifetime customer.\xa0 Many of these cards act as little siblings to their rewards card brothers
column184: giving students a chance to earn rewards without needing as much of a credit history. Check out these best credit cards for students.'
column185: 'Whether it’s a roadside stand or a shop on Etsy
column186: small businesses have unique credit needs.\xa0 Business credit cards offer benefits tailored to commerce and offer a way to keep personal and business expenses separate.\xa0 If you are just starting out
column187: one of our best cards for new businesses may do the trick.\xa0 If you operate an established business
column188: even if it’s a side hustle
column189: check out our best business credit cards list to learn about your options.'
column190: 'If you only stay at Hyatt or only shop at Pottery Barn
column191: it may make sense for you to pick up a co-branded credit card for that store
column192: airline or hotel chain.\xa0 By doing so you’ll earn points and perks within their ecosystem
column193: which you can then use to further your love of the brand.'
column194: 'A credit card issuer is the bank that issues
column196: the card you’re applying for. Some credit cards have the issuing bank as part of their name
column197: like Chase or Citibank. Others work behind the scenes as the issuing bank for credit cards that may not be part of a traditional financial institution
column199: 'Card networks process the payments between the buyer and the merchant. There are four major credit card networks: Mastercard
column201: American Express and Discover. American Express and Discover are unique in that they are also card issuing companies in addition to owning a card network.'
column202: 'A credit card that’s co-branded is one that’s issued in partnership with a certain retailer or service provider. Popular brands like JetBlue
column203: Hyatt and Disney have all partnered with credit card companies to offer cards that earn rewards in their loyalty programs and offer brand specific perks. Typically a co-branded credit card will offer rewards and or other perks within the brand.'
column204: 'Both Visa and Mastercard are payment processing networks and it shouldn’t matter to you as a consumer which one your card is on when it comes to making a payment. But both cards offer perks and benefits specific to their brand and type of card within the brand. For example
column205: a traditional Visa or Visa Platinum card may offer roadside dispatch services and lost card replacement assistance. A Visa Signature card may offer these benefits plus travel insurances and protections. Each individual Visa card will come with different benefits based on the type of Visa and the perks selected by the issuing bank to include.'
column206: 'The same holds true for Mastercard: There are different types of Mastercards with varying perks and benefits depending on the type of Mastercard. The most notable feature some Mastercards offer that some Visas don’t is cell phone coverage. You shouldn’t choose a card based on the issuing network however. Instead think of any extras offered by the payment networks as a bonus
column207: with the focus on the main features of the card itself.'
column208: 'To view rates and fees for Blue Cash Preferred® Card from American Express please visit this page.'
column209: 'To view rates and fees for The Platinum Card® from American Express please visit this page.'
column210: 'The best credit card is the one that rewards your personal spending habits in a way that makes sense for your redemption preferences. Look for cards that offer bonus points in categories you spend heavily in
column213: make sure the type of rewards you’re earning lines up with your lifestyle. Travel rewards are popular
column214: but cash back can make more sense for many customers.'
column215: 'There’s no one right number of credit cards to have. That’s because everyone’s financial profile and goals are unique to their particular circumstances. Having multiple credit cards can either be a boon or a bust depending on how you acquire and use the cards.'
column217: 'Having more than one or two credit cards can be a good fit for most people as a credit card allows you to establish credit history. A good credit history over time will save you money as it can help you qualify for lower rates on other types of loans
column219: auto loans or student loans. Since many rewards cards offer tiered rewards in different areas of spending
column220: for someone with a careful strategy of pairing rewards cards
column221: it can be more beneficial than just one card.'
column223: 'Too many credit cards can entice you to overspend and take on more debt than you can handle. And if you’re considering adding more credit cards to your portfolio
column224: keep in mind that every time you apply for a credit card
column225: the issuer will run a credit check to determine whether or not to approve you. This can ding your score. And
column226: some issuers will turn you down if you apply for too many cards in too short a period of time.'
column227: 'But for someone who can pay their bills in full and on time
column228: and doesn’t mind the effort of juggling multiple cards
column229: owning several cards can be part of a plan that works for them.'
column230: 'Secured credit cards are typically the easiest to be approved for and are designed for people who have no or bad credit. For anyone with average or better credit
column231: you may be approved for traditional
column232: unsecured credit cards as well. Typically cards with no or low rewards have less stringent application requirements. You may want to check for pre-approved offers personalized for you to improve your odds.'
column234: you’ll find the best solution for you is exactly that: personal. However
column235: several card issuers consistently rank on the list of best credit cards. Favorites like American Express
column237: Chase and Citi offer a wide range of rewards cards and also bundle consumer protections and cardholder benefits.'
column238: ""\n                Caroline Lupini is the Credit Card and Travel Analyst for Forbes Advisor. She's a credit card enthusiast and digital nomad who has leveraged credit cards to travel around the world for next to nothing
column239: often in style. Prior to working for Forbes
column240: she contributed to other leading publications in the credit cards and rewards space. She would like to visit every country and try as many different local culinary specialties as possible.            ""
column241: '\n                Dia Adams is a noted family travel expert and a real-life Mom of two teens in the DC Metro area. She has visited over 45 countries and lived in Thailand
column243: and Ireland (where her son was born). Her kids have over 20 stamps in their own passports. Her passion lies in showing families how to travel more while keeping their savings and sanity.  Her guidebook

                Apr 1, 2022, 12:19pm', 'A balance transfer card can be a powerful tool in your debt-busting arsenal. A 0% APR offer on a credit card can save money by having all of your payments go towards knocking out the principal balance instead of some being siphoned away to pay interest charges.', 'Most balance transfer cards charge a balance transfer fee. When calculating which balance transfer card makes the most sense for you, make sure you factor in this fee, along with the amount of debt you’re looking to transfer and the months you need to pay off the bill.', 'You can use our balance transfer calculator to help determine which balance transfer card makes the most sense for your needs. For help getting started with some of the best options available today, we’ve rounded up our best picks below.', 'N/A', '$0', '13.24% - 25.24% Variable APR', '

							Excellent, Good							(700 - 749)						', 'Those looking to consolidate debt and pay it off over time will appreciate the long introductory offer on balance transfers. A $0 annual fee further enhances its frugal appeal. On the downside, this card is light on perks and comes with a heavy balance transfer fee.', 'N/A', '$0', '14.99% - 24.99% (Variable)', '

You'll also get a long intro APR offer on purchases. However, there is no rewards program nor any welcome bonus, making this truly a "simple" card for those looking to hold a balance for a long period of time.', '20,000 points', '$0', '13.74% - 23.74% (Variable)', '
						
							Excellent, Good							(700 - 749)						', 'The Citi Rewards+® Card is an intriguing option as an everyday card for small purchases. In terms of rewards earnings, Citi rounds up all purchases to the next 10 points. Meaning, that a $3 purchase will earn 10 points. Earn additional rewards with a 10% redemption bonus each year (on up to 100,000 redeemed points) plus an increased earning rate on supermarkets and gas spending up to the annual $6,000 cap— with no annual fee.', 'Up to 5X Reward Rate', '
Earn 5% cash back in categories that rotate quarterly on up to $1,500 when enrolled, 5% on travel purchased throughRead More ', '$200 bonus', '$0', '14.99% - 23.74% Variable', '
						
							Excellent, Good							(700 - 749)						', 'This card has the brawn to handle just about all of your credit card spending needs without an over-inflated price tag. The card has an annual fee of $0, yet comes with a pumped-up earnings structure that covers a wide swath of expenses including travel, drugstores and dining plus rotating quarterly bonus categories in areas many households are likely to find appealing. ', 'N/A', '$0', '5.99% - 18.00% variable', '
						
							Average to Excellent							(650 - 699)						', "Many people skip credit union cards because they assume they won't qualify.  Navy Federal might be easier to join than you realize, and the card doesn't charge a fee for balance transfers, making for a low cost balance transfer option.", 'Not all balance transfer cards are created equally. To generate our list of top picks for balance transfer credit cards, Forbes Advisor reviewed dozens of credit cards with balance transfer options across a broad spectrum of issuers.', 'We weighed a number of factors including the length of a card’s balance transfer offer, any transfer fees plus any welcome bonuses and credit card fees as part of ownership. We also considered the usefulness of the card beyond the intro balance transfer period including if it earned rewards on purchases.', 'If you’re looking to pay less interest on your existing debt, the Wells Fargo Reflect℠ Card is a straightforward choice. It carries no annual fee and new cardholders get a generous introductory period to pay down balances. Just make sure to make that balance transfer within the eligibility window or you’ll be subject to a higher balance transfer fee.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Balance Transfer Offer: Get a 0% intro APR for 18 months from account opening on purchases and qualifying balance transfers. An intro APR extension of up to 3 months with on-time minimum payments during the intro and extension periods is available. A variable APR of 13.24% to 25.24% variable APR applies after that. Balance transfers made within 120 days qualify for the intro rate and fee of 3% then a balance transfer fee of up to 5%, min $5 applies.', 'Balance Transfer Fee: The fee for a balance transfer is up to 5%; min: $5.', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: Although there are no rewards with this card, it does come with some money-saving protections like up to $600 in cell phone protection when you pay your monthly bill with the card (subject to a $25 deductible) and access to roadside dispatch.', 'Read our full review of the Wells Fargo Reflect℠ Card.', 'If you’re looking for a long introductory period to pay off a big purchase or shed existing debt, the U.S. Bank Visa® Platinum Card is a top choice. It’s extra-lengthy offer on both balance transfers and purchases can give you the breathing room you’re seeking.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Balance Transfer Offer: Get a 0% intro APR on purchases and balance transfers for 20 billing cycles, followed by a variable APR of 14.74% - 24.74%. A balance transfer fee of either 3% or $5 applies, whichever is greater.', 'Balance Transfer Fee: Either 3% of the amount of each transfer or $5 minimum, whichever is greater', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: Beyond the long intro APR offer, the card doesn’t offer much else. There’s no perks like rewards or other benefits, making this card all about the 0% period.', 'Read our full review of the U.S. Bank Visa® Platinum Card.', 'The Citi® Double Cash Card’s 2% cash back on all purchases—1% when purchases are made and another 1% when they’re paid off—provides generous and simple cash-back rewards on every purchase.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Balance Transfer Offer: Get a 0% intro APR on balance transfers for 18 months. After that, the standard variable APR will be 14.24% - 24.24%, based on creditworthiness. There is also an intro balance transfer fee of either $5 or 3% of the amount of each transfer, whichever is greater, completed within the first 4 months of account opening. After that, the fee will be 5% of each transfer (minimum $5).', 'Balance Transfer Fee: There is an intro balance transfer fee of 3% of each transfer (minimum $5) completed within the first 4 months of account opening. A balance transfer fee of 5% of each transfer ($5 minimum) applies if completed after 4 months of account opening.', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: Unlike similar cards with balance transfer offers, the Citi Double Cash has staying power long past the end of the promotional period.', 'Read our full review of the Citi® Double Cash Card.', 'The BankAmericard® credit card offers a generous introductory APR period on both purchases and balance transfers and comes with an option to opt-in to overdraft protection too.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Balance Transfer Offer: Get a 0% introductory APR for 18 billing cycles for purchases, and for any balance transfers made in the first 60 days. After the intro APR offer ends, a variable APR of 13.24% – 23.24% Variable APR will apply. A 3% fee (min $10) applies to all balance transfers.', 'Balance Transfer Fee: Either $10 or 3% of the amount of each transaction, whichever is greater.', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: Beyond the intro APR offer, the card doesn’t earn rewards or come with other meaningful benefits, making it unlikely that it’s a long-term choice after the introductory period ends.', 'Read our full review of the BankAmericard® credit card.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Balance Transfer Offer: Get a 0% intro APR for 18 months from account opening on purchases and balance transfers, then a variable APR of 14.99 - 23.74%. An intro transfer fee of either $5 or 3% of the amount of each transfer, whichever is greater, applies on transfers made within 60 days of account opening. After that, a fee of either $5 or 5% of the amount of each transfer, whichever is greater applies', 'Balance Transfer Fee: Either $5 or 5% of the amount of each transfer, whichever is greater.', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The card comes with some unique benefits for a balance transfer card, like the opportunity to receive an automatic one-time review for a higher credit limit after spending $500 and making payments on-time in your first six months; and the chance to qualify for up to a 2% APR reduction each year after spending $1,000 and paying on-time. But if you’re looking for the longest runway possible to pay down your debt, other cards offer longer 0% APR periods.', 'Most balance transfer cards require you to make your balance transfer within the first month or two of opening your account in order to qualify for their 0% intro APR offer. But the Citi® Diamond Preferred® Card has one of the most generous time periods of any card on the market, giving you four months from the date you open your account to transfer debt to the card.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Balance Transfer Offer: Get a 0% intro APR for 21 months on eligible balance transfers from the date of the first transfer and 0% intro APR for 12 months on purchases from date of account opening. After that the variable APR will be 13.99% - 23.99% based on your creditworthiness. Balance transfers must be completed within 4 months of account opening. A balance transfer fee of either $5 or 5% of the amount of each transfer, whichever is greater, applies.', 'Balance Transfer Fee: Balance transfer fee applies with this offer 5% of each balance transfer; $5 minimum.', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The Citi Diamond Preferred doesn’t come with a lot of frills, but like most Citi cards, you’ll get access to the Citi Concierge and you can choose which day of the month for your payment due date. You’ll also get special event access through Citi Entertainment®', 'Read our full review of the Citi® Diamond Preferred® Card.', 'If you’re seeking a long time period to chip away at a balance, the Citi Simplicity® Card deserves a look. With no late fees or penalty interest rate, it’s a solid choice among balance transfer cards when you’re looking to shed debt with a side of extra flexibility.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Balance Transfer Offer: Get a 0% intro APR for 21 months on balance transfers from date of first transfer, and 0% intro APR for 12 months on purchases from date of account opening. After that, the variable APR will be 14.99% - 24.99%, based on your creditworthiness. Balance transfers must be completed within 4 months of account opening. There is a balance transfer fee of either $5 or 5% of the amount of each transfer, whichever is greater.', 'Balance Transfer Fee: Balance transfer fee applies with this offer 5% of each balance transfer; $5 minimum', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The Citi Simplicity packs a nice punch of triple zeros: No annual fee, no penalty interest rate and no late fees. The card also comes with Citi perks including Citi Concierge service.', 'Read our full review of the Citi Simplicity® Card.', 'If you want a balance transfer card that you’re likely to use even after the intro APR period, the Citi Rewards+® Card could be a worthy addition to your wallet. The card earns 2 ThankYou Points per dollar at supermarkets and gas stations for the first $6,000 in spending per year and 1 ThankYou Point per dollar on all other eligible purchases. Plus, for a limited time, earn 5 ThankYou Points per dollar on air travel and hotels up to $6,000 in the first 12 months of account opening. And, the card will automatically round up to the nearest 10 points on every purchase, potentially snagging you a few extra rewards on every purchase.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Balance Transfer Offer: Get a 0% intro APR on balance transfers for 15 months from date of first transfer and on purchases from date of account opening. After that, the variable APR will be 13.74% - 23.74%, based on your creditworthiness. An intro balance transfer fee of either 3% of each transfer or a minimum amount of $5 within the first 4 months of account opening applies. After that, the amount of each balance transfer will be 5% of each transfer (minimum $5) applies.', 'Balance Transfer Fee: A balance transfer fee of 5% of each transfer ($5 minimum) applies if completed after 4 months of account opening.', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: One caveat about those rewards: Redeeming earnings on this card as a statement credit or straight cash back is worth less than one cent per point. To get the full value from your ThankYou points, redeem them towards a student loan or mortgage payment or combine them with another ThankYou points earning card such as the Citi Premier® Card.', 'Read our full review of the Citi Rewards+® Card.', 'jIf you’re looking for the needle in the haystack—a balance transfer card that also earns rewards across a wide swath of categories—look no further. The Chase Freedom Flex℠ fits the bill, earning 5% cash back on up to $1,500 in categories that rotate quarterly (requires activation), 5% on travel purchased through Chase Ultimate Rewards®, 3% on dining and drugstores and 1% on all other purchases.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Balance Transfer Offer: Get a 0% intro APR for 15 months from account opening on purchases and balance transfers, then a variable APR of 14.99 - 23.74% applies. Intro balance transfer fee of either $5 or 3% of the amount of each transfer, whichever is greater in the first 60 days, after that either $5 or 5% of the amount of each transfer, whichever is greater applies.', 'Balance Transfer Fee: Either $5 or 5% of the amount of each transfer, whichever is greater.', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: Be aware that in order to earn that 5% rate on travel, you have to book through the Chase Ultimate Rewards travel center. The card runs on the Mastercard network, which means it comes with some nice extras like trip and purchase insurances and protections.', 'Read our full review of the Chase Freedom Flex℠.', 'The multiple zeros associated with the Navy Federal Credit Union Platinum Credit Card* make it a hero for those seeking to tame high-interest credit card debt. The card, which is issued on either the Visa or the Mastercard network, carries no annual fee, no balance transfer fees and comes with an introductory 0% APR offer on balance transfers.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Balance Transfer Offer: Get a 0% on balance transfers for 12 months, followed by a regular APR of 5.99%-18.00% variable on both purchases and balance transfers. Balance transfers must be completed within 30 days of account opening.', 'Balance Transfer Fee: None', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The lack of a balance transfer fee makes this card a rarity among balance transfer cards, but the promo period is shorter than that of other cards. Another potential snag is that you have to join Navy Federal’s credit union to apply for the card, although nearly anyone with a military-affiliated family member is eligible.', 'Read our full review of the Navy Federal Credit Union Platinum Credit Card*.', 'A balance transfer lets you save on existing high-interest debt by transferring your balance to a card with a lower interest rate or one with a 0% APR offer on balance transfers. Sometimes there is a balance transfer fee to move debt from one card to another, typically between 3% to 5% of the amount being transferred.', 'This fee will add on to your debt load, so do the math before deciding to transfer your debt to another card. If the amount you’re paying in balance transfer fees is greater than what you’d save on interest by doing the transfer, then it’s probably not a good money move.', 'A 0% balance transfer is when you shift debt to a card offering a promotional 0% interest rate on the amount that you transfer. This can save you money as any payments you make toward the balance on a 0% card will go entirely toward paying down the principal, instead of accruing additional finance charges.', 'These offers are not infinite and typically last anywhere from six months to nearly two years. Once the 0% APR promotional period expires, any remaining balance will be subject to the card’s regular rate of interest. Keep in mind that a 0% balance transfer may not be entirely free as there may be a balance transfer fee.', 'The main goal of a balance transfer is to save money on existing debt. A balance transfer card can save money by allowing you to transfer your debt to a new credit card ideally with a lower rate. Once you’ve transferred the debt, you’ll make payments to the new card. Ideally, you wouldn’t charge anything to your new balance transfer card so you can focus on paying down the balance.', 'Since most (but not all) credit cards come with balance transfer fees, it typically only makes sense to make this move if the new card has a lower interest rate than your existing debt or comes with a low promotional offer on the new card.', 'A balance transfer fee is the amount you’ll be charged to move your debt from one card to another. Typically it’s 3% or 5% of the amount being transferred. Before applying for a balance transfer card it’s important to consider any fees you may have to pay as this will add onto your existing debt. Do the math to make sure you’ll actually end up saving money by doing a balance transfer.', 'It typically takes anywhere from two to seven days for your transfer request to be completed, but it depends on the issuer of the card you’re seeking to transfer a balance to.', 'For example, American Express says it typically takes from five to seven days for a transfer from another bank to be completed but it could take as long as six weeks. Citibank says on its site it can take from two to 21 days and Chase says most transfers are complete within two weeks.', 'The exact time for your transfer will likely depend on both the bank you’re transferring the debt to and the bank you’re transferring the debt from.', 'First, choose the card you want to transfer a balance to. If you’re applying for a new balance transfer card online, you’ll have the option to choose to transfer a balance to the new card during the application process. Otherwise, you can speak to an agent at the issuing bank for your new card to make the transfer.', 'Be sure to read the card’s fine print and understand the terms and conditions of the card you’re transferring a balance to. Things to look for include:', 'Be aware that you won’t actually find out how much of a credit limit you’ll have on the new card until after you apply. This is important because you may not get approved for a line of credit as large as the amount you’re looking to transfer.', 'A 0% balance transfer works the same way as any other balance transfer. After you choose the card with an introductory 0% APR balance transfer offer, you can opt to make the transfer during the application process, or reach out to someone at the issuing bank to shift a balance to the new card.', 'When looking for the right balance transfer card for your circumstances, ideally you’ll search for a balance transfer card with low or no balance transfer fees to minimize the cost when you do a transfer. Keep in mind you’ll also need to choose a card from an issuing bank other than the one you’re looking to transfer debt from since banks won’t let you transfer debt from one of their cards to another. Finally, consider the length of your balance transfer. The longer it is, the more time you’ll have to pay off your debt before interest piles up, but the cards with the longest 0% APR offers may also have higher balance transfer fees.', 'Other considerations include:', 'The process to apply for a balance transfer credit card is similar to applying for any other type of credit card. First, determine which card might be the best fit for your goals. You can then typically apply online or in-person at the issuing bank where applicable. You’ll be required to provide your name, a U.S. address and your Social Security or ITIN number. You may also be asked to provide your income and housing costs. This information, along with a hard credit pull, will factor into how much a credit limit you’ll be granted on a new card.', 'While a balance transfer card can be an appealing option to help pay down debt, it’s important to consider the pros and cons before opening up a new card.', 'There are other options to help you get some breathing room on high-interest debt outside of a balance transfer card. Here are some to consider:', 'If you’re overwhelmed by the amount you need to pay on your monthly credit card bill or you can no longer afford to make the payment at the levels you once did, consider just making the minimum monthly payment to avoid affecting your credit or going into default on your card. It may not help you get out of debt quicker, but it can delay any adverse effects to your overall credit profile.', 'If you aren’t eligible for a balance transfer card or you don’t want to apply for a new line of credit, it may make sense to calculate various repayment scenarios using a credit card payoff calculator. This may help you feel more in control of your financial situation and can help you prioritize your spending.', 'If you’re stuck with high-interest credit card debt, but don’t qualify for a better offer on a balance transfer card, it may make sense to work on improving your credit score. This takes time, but there are tools, like Experian Boost, that may help you nudge your score up enough within a few months that you become eligible for a better offer on a balance transfer card.', 'A personal or debt consolidation loan may be available to you at a lower interest rate than what you’re currently paying on your cards. If a thin or recovering credit profile is keeping you from qualifying for the best offers, you may have a better chance of getting a loan with a cosigner.', 'If you’re looking to pay off one credit balance using another card, this generally isn’t possible. Banks don’t allow you to pay your credit card balance using another credit card. Typically, payments via check, electronic bank transfer or money order are the only acceptable methods of payment.', 'But a balance transfer credit card is the exception to that rule. If you can transfer a balance from a high-interest credit card to one with a 0% APR offer or even a lower ongoing interest rate, you can save money.', 'Once you’ve chosen the card you want to transfer a balance to, you can apply online or via phone call with the bank. During the application process, you’ll have the option to transfer your balance to the new card. If the card you’re transferring a balance to has a balance transfer fee, that will be automatically added to the total balance you’ll owe on the new card.', 'Keep in mind you generally can’t transfer a balance from one card to another card issued by the same bank, and some banks will have limits, regardless of your credit score, of how much you’re allowed to transfer to a new card.', 'A balance transfer APR is the amount of interest you’ll be charged on your debt when you move it to a new card. Some cards offer 0% interest for an introductory period of time, other cards may offer a low ongoing interest rate. The main goal in doing a balance transfer is to save money on interest, so ideally the APR of the card you’re transferring a balance to will be less than the interest rate on your current card.', 'Every new line of credit can ding your score. So if you’re applying for a new balance transfer card, it can have an impact on your credit score. Your score may also be impacted by a balance transfer if the amount you’re transferring to a new card is at or close to the total allowable credit limit on the new card. That’s because your debt-to-available credit ratio makes up a significant role in determining your overall score.', 'But, if you have a plan to use a balance transfer to help you pay down your debt more quickly than you could without doing a transfer, in the long run, your overall debt load will be lower and that will in turn have a positive impact on your credit score.', 'Balance transfer business credit cards function in the same way as personal balance transfer cards. Before making a transfer from one business credit card to another, be sure to consider the terms of the offer, how long any introductory APR offer will last as well as any balance transfer fees you may incur.', 'It’s also important to remember that most business credit cards come with a personal guarantee, which means that your payment behavior, good or bad, can affect your personal credit score. So a late or missed payment on a balance transfer business card will affect your credit standing.', 'Yes, but the limit is determined by the issuing bank and your creditworthiness. For example, Chase caps balance transfers at $15,000. But there’s no guarantee that you’ll get approved for a limit on a new card that high. If you’re only approved for, say, a $5,000 limit on a balance transfer card with any bank, then $5,000 is going to be the maximum amount of debt you can carry on the new card.', 'Also remember that any balance transfer fees will count toward your limit and have to be factored in when doing a transfer. So, if you’re approved for a $5,000 credit limit but there’s a 5% balance transfer fee, you’ll only be able to transfer $4,750, since you’ll have to include a $250 balance transfer fee.', "
                Robin Saks Frankel is a credit cards and personal finance writer for Forbes Advisor. Previously, she covered credit cards and related content at other national web publications including NerdWallet, Bankrate and HerMoney. She's been featured as a personal finance expert in outlets including CNBC, Business Insider, CBS Marketplace, and has appeared on or contributed to Fox News, CBS Radio, ABC Radio, NPR, International Business Times and NBC, ABC and CBS TV affiliates nationwide.  Follow her on Twitter at @robinsaks.            ", '
                Dia Adams is a noted family travel expert and a real-life Mom of two teens in the DC Metro area. She has visited over 45 countries and lived in Thailand, China, and Ireland (where her son was born). Her kids have over 20 stamps in their own passports. Her passion lies in showing families how to travel more while keeping their savings and sanity.  Her guidebook, Disney World Hacks, is a bestseller on Amazon.            ']

							Good/Excellent							(700 - 749)						', 'The Wells Fargo Business Platinum Credit Card is a solid everyday rewards card for small businesses — especially those in need of multiple employee cards. The 1.5% cashback option is a great offer. The reward points option, not so much.', 'When considering the best cash-back credit cards for businesses, we compared not only the various earning structures but the overall combination of benefits each card offered. We went through dozens of options and considered the following factors when it came time to cherry-pick our top choices: rewards rate, credit card fees, ease of use, welcome offers and cardholder perks.', 'The Ink Business Unlimited® Credit Card earns flat rate cash back on all your spending without an annual fee. This card also offers an introductory APR that can help you save money on interest.', 'Rewards: 1.5% cash back rewards on every business purchase', 'Welcome Bonus: With this card you’ll earn $750 bonus cash back after spending $7,500 on purchases in the first 3 months from account opening', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: Earning a consistent rate of cash back for each dollar spent with no annual fee is a winning proposition for business owners who want to earn easy rewards without hassle. Since rewards earned with this card are part of the Chase Ultimate Rewards program, you can also redeem your earnings for statement credits, gift cards, travel and more. Or take the rewards as straight cash back to use however you want.', 'If you pair this card with a premium Chase card like the Ink Business Preferred® Credit Card, Chase Sapphire Preferred® Card or Chase Sapphire Reserve®, you’ll unlock the ability to redeem your earnings as Chase Ultimate Rewards. Points could then be redeemed for travel for 25% to 50% more value, depending on which card you have, or you could transfer your points at a 1:1 rate to travel partners including United and Hyatt.', 'Read our full review of the Ink Business Unlimited® Credit Card.', 'Designed for businesses with over a million dollars in annual sales, the Wells Fargo Business Elite Signature Card* comes bursting with travel perks and protections for a card with an annual fee of $125 annual fee (waived first year).', 'Rewards: 1.5% cash back per dollar spent or earn 1 point per dollar spent and receive 5,000 bonus points when the company spend is $10,000 or more in any monthly billing period', 'Welcome Bonus: $1,000 one-time cash back bonus or 100,000 bonus points after spending $15,000 in the first three months of account open date', 'Annual Fee: $125 annual fee (waived first year)', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The card offers an annual up to $100 travel incidental fee reimbursement and up to 200 free employee cards. But don’t be fooled by the “elite” in its name as this card doesn’t offer plush perks like lounge access or a TSA PreCheck/Global Entry fee waiver.', 'Read our full review of the Wells Fargo Business Elite Signature Card*.', 'The Ink Business Cash® Credit Card comes with lucrative earning categories at high rewards caps. Since there’s no annual fee, you don’t have to worry about spending enough to break even on the annual fee. Anyone who spends in areas typical to a business may find this card makes a good match for their expenditures.', 'Rewards: 5% cash back on the first $25,000 spent in combined purchases at office supply stores and on internet, cable and phone services each account anniversary year and 2% cash back on the first $25,000 spent in combined purchases at gas stations and restaurants each account anniversary year. Earn 1% cash back on all other purchases', 'Welcome Bonus: $750 bonus cash back after spending $7,500 on purchases in the first 3 months from account opening', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The biggest potential drawback is that there are caps in the bonus categories. If you spend a ton of money on business purchases in the elevated earnings categories each year, you might ultimately earn more with a flat-rate earnings card.', 'Read our full review of the Ink Business Cash® Credit Card.', 'The Amazon Business Prime American Express Card* is a logical choice for businesses that either buy a lot from the online store, spend a lot on the Amazon Web Service cloud platform or both. That’s because it earns high rewards on spending within the Amazon ecosystem and decent rewards on other areas of spending too. Or, opt for no-interest financing instead of rewards and buy yourself some time to pay off a large purchase.', 'Rewards: 5% back in rewards or 90 Days Terms on eligible U.S. purchases at Amazon Business, AWS, Amazon.com and Whole Foods Market with an eligible Prime membership. The 5% reward rate applies to the first $120,000 in purchases each calendar year. Earn 2% at U.S. restaurants, U.S. gas stations, and on wireless telephone services purchased directly from U.S. service providers and 1% on other purchases', 'Welcome Bonus: Amazon.com gift card upon approval for the Amazon Business Prime American Express Card
', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: You can use your rewards towards more purchases on Amazon or take as a statement credit towards previous purchases. But if your spending doesn’t align with the bonus categories on this card or you simply don’t want to have the Business Prime membership required to apply for this card, seek another option.', 'Read our full review of the Amazon Business Prime American Express Card*.', 'The American Express Blue Business Cash™ Card (Terms apply, see rates and fees) is a no-fuss business credit card that lets you earn rewards without an annual fee. Consider this card if you want to earn considerable rewards on all your spending without tracking categories and you typically spend $50,000 or less a year.', 'Rewards: 2% cash back on all eligible purchases on up to $50,000 per calendar year, then 1%', 'Welcome Bonus: $250\xa0statement credit after making\xa0$3,000 in purchases within the first\xa03\xa0months of account opening', 'Annual Fee: No annual fee', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: There’s no annual fee and no over-the-limit worries as the American Express Blue Business Cash™ Card offers flexible spending limits to eligible cardholders if your needs fluctuate from month-to-month. But a business that routinely spends more than $50,000 in a year would fare better with a card that doesn’t cap earnings rates.', 'Read our full review of the American Express Blue Business Cash™ Card.', 'The U.S. Bank Business Triple Cash Rewards World Elite™ Mastercard® comes with generous rewards on typical areas of business spending and comes with a 0% introductory APR on purchase and balance transfers for 15 billing cycles, followed by a regular variable APR of 14.24% - 23.24%. An intro offer on both purchases and balance transfers is uncommon for a business credit card.', 'Rewards: 3% cash back on eligible purchases at gas stations, office supply stores, cell phone service providers and restaurants and 1% cash back on all other eligible net purchases', 'Welcome Bonus: $500 in cash back after spending $4,500 in the first 150 days of opening an account', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: If the card’s bonus categories don’t align with where your business spends, another card will be a more rewarding choice. Although the balance transfer offer is a nice perk, there is a balance transfer fee: Either 3% of the amount of each transfer or $5 minimum, whichever is greater', 'Read our full review of the U.S. Bank Business Triple Cash Rewards World Elite™ Mastercard®.', 'If your business expenses vary from month to month, the U.S. Bank Business Leverage® Visa Signature® Card*
will adapt by automatically adjusting rewards each month to where you spend the most. The card earns elevated rewards in your top two spending categories each month from an approved list.', 'Rewards: 2 points per dollar on eligible net purchases made in the top two categories where the most is spent each month and 1 point per dollar on all other eligible net purchases', 'Welcome Bonus: 75,000 points worth $750 cash back by spending $7,500 in eligible net purchases within the first four months of account opening', 'Annual Fee: $0 intro annual fee, then $95', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: There’s no need to opt-in to bonus categories or track where you’re spending the most since the card will automatically adjust to how you spend. Rewards expire five years from the end of the quarter in which they were earned, which can be cumbersome to track. If you consistently spend heavily in more than two categories, you’ll likely fare better with a flat-rate rewards card.', 'Read our full review of the U.S. Bank Business Leverage® Visa Signature® Card*.', 'The Bank of America® Business Advantage Customized Cash Rewards Mastercard® credit card is an excellent cash-back small business credit card offering generous rewards in a variety of categories of interest to small business owners. For those small business owners who have an existing banking relationship with Bank of America or Merrill and can achieve the Platinum level in the Preferred Rewards program, this card becomes best-in-class.', "Rewards: 3% cash back in the category of your choice, 2% cash back on dining purchases and unlimited 1% cash back on all other purchases. You'll earn 3% and 2% cash back on the first $50,000 in combined choice category/dining purchases each calendar year and 1% thereafter", 'Welcome Bonus: $300 statement credit online bonus after making at least $3,000 in net purchases within 90 days of account opening', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: Earning bonus cash back in popular categories is nice, but keep in mind that you’ll only earn bonus rewards up to a spending cap.', 'But this card leaps to the front of the pack for Bank of America customers who are part of the Preferred Rewards program. Depending on the total amount a Preferred Rewards Member has in their qualifying accounts, they can earn 25% to 75% more rewards for each dollar they spend on their Bank of America rewards cards.', 'Read our full review of the Bank of America® Business Advantage Customized Cash Rewards Mastercard® credit card.', 'The Wells Fargo Business Platinum Credit Card* has a unique choose-your-own-rewards-adventure structure. Holders of the card can either earn a flat cash back rate or opt to earn one rewards point for every dollar spent. If you typically spend more than $2,000 a month on a credit card, the flat rate is likely a better choice.', 'Rewards: choose your rewards: Cash Back or Rewards Points. Cash Back option: Earn 1.5% cash back on every $1 spent; Reward Points option: Earn 1 point on every $1 spent and receive 1,000 bonus points when your company spend is $1,000 or more in any monthly billing period', 'Welcome Bonus: one-time $300 cash back bonus or 30,000 bonus points when you enroll in the Business Card Rewards Program and spend $3,000 in the first three months of account open date', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: Having to choose which rewards structure you want can be a nuisance, especially if you aren’t sure what your average monthly spend will be. But if you know which style will work best for you, that’s a moot point. You’ll get up to 99 additional employee cards at no additional cost and for those who choose to receive points, a 10% rebate when you redeem your earnings online.', 'Read our full review of the Wells Fargo Business Platinum Credit Card* .', 'A business credit card is any credit card designed for and issued to businesses. These cards often come with business-oriented benefits and rewards. Reward earning with business credit cards is often oriented at common business expense categories, including office supplies and internet or phone service.', 'Business credit cards may still require personal guarantees from primary cardholders in the event a business lacks sufficient business credit history or collateral. The cards may help smaller businesses including sole proprietorships keep owners’ personal and business expenses separate.', 'It may be tempting to opt for a personal card instead of a business card, especially considering many business cards will require a personal guarantee to receive approval for. The benefits, rewards and fees of a business card are structured to fit the operations of businesses and not those of an individual. For instance, business cards often offer the ability to issue employee cards and sometimes offer compatibility with Quickbooks or other business-grade accounting software.', 'Keeping expenses separate with a business credit card isn’t only an expediency when it comes to accounting—legal implications complicate the inconvenience of sorting out personal and business spending. “Piercing the corporate veil” is the casual term for mixing business and pleasure from a legal standpoint. The liability protections offered by limited liability company status or corporate statuses can be inadvertently surrendered by failing to keep business and personal expenses separate. To learn more about reasons to consider a business credit card over a personal card, check out our guide.', 'The business credit card application process resembles the personal credit card application process but often requires additional information which may include the business’ name, tax ID, incorporation status and more. Most issuers make applying easy and convenient via online application forms, but calling your issuer of choice may be just as convenient. To learn more about the application process, see our guide to applying for credit cards.', 'Choosing the form in which you’d prefer your business credit card rewards involves weighing both how you plan to spend the rewards and several other factors, like the extra benefits the cards offer. For businesses with employees who travel often the travel insurances and protections usually associated with a travel card may make more sense, since these benefits can often save much more than the sum of any rewards provided when a flight is delayed or baggage is lost.', 'Cardholders will earn a percentage of their spending back as cash-back “rewards”. For instance, 1% cash back on a $100 purchase will see the cardholder earn $1 in cash-back rewards. These rewards are usually returned to the cardholder as a statement credit or deposit into an account upon redemption. Cash-back rewards are not a discount on purchases—all purchases must be paid off in full.', 'Every time you make a purchase with your cash-back business card, you’ll earn a percentage back on your spending. The amount you’ll earn will depend on your particular card’s terms. Those earnings are accumulated in your card’s account and you can redeem them according to your card’s protocols. Some cards let you redeem your cash earnings in any amount, at any time, while others require a minimum balance to cash out.', 'The exact way you’ll receive your cash back also varies by card, with some letting you take those rewards as a statement credit against your balance and others also allowing you to take actual cash back.', 'Business credit cards offering cash-back rewards can be, well, rewarding. But these cards also often come with a few disadvantages.', 'Which credit card is right for your business will depend entirely on the priorities and preferences of your business. Rewards are often earned and redeemed as cash back or travel rewards and each comes with a set of advantages and disadvantages—for instance, travel rewards cannot always be redeemed for cash (or, in some cases, can only be redeemed for a lesser cash value compared to the value of a travel redemption).', 'Most small business owners should at least consider a business credit card, but cash-back-specific business credit cards may not be right for all businesses. Check out our list of the best business credit cards for an overview of what else business credit cards may be able to offer.', 'A cash-back business card can deliver modest dividends on spending for many businesses, but all business owners should carefully consider whether a cash-back card is better than other types of business credit cards. Be sure to weigh additional benefits, credit limits and introductory and standard APRs against the reward potential of cards you consider for your business.', 'To view rates and fees for American Express Blue Business Cash™ Card please visit this page.', 'There’s no one best cash-back business card that will earn the most rewards for everyone. The credit card that will earn you the highest cash-back rewards will depend on your business’ spending habits and tolerance for tracking rewards.', 'For example, the Ink Business Preferred® Credit Card earns 3 points per dollar on the first $150,000 spent on travel and select business categories each account anniversary year and 1 point per dollar on all other purchases. If these categories match up with your company’s expenses, the rewards can really add up. But it requires tracking your spending carefully.', 'If you prefer a simple cash-back scheme, a card\xa0that earns the same flat rate on all your business spending could be a better fit.', 'Although business credit cards typically offer higher credit limits than personal cards, if you’re looking for the highest possible limit on a cash-back business credit card, know that the limit you’ll actually receive will depend on your credit profile and the amount of business revenue you claim on your application.', 'If you expect that you’ll occasionally need to spend more on a card than your credit limit, consider a business charge card. With a charge card you’ll have to pay the balance in full every month, unlike a credit card where you can carry a balance. A charge card also doesn’t have a preset spending limit which means you won’t have to worry about being denied for a large purchase. However, the issuer will use your spending patterns to determine an upper limit on the amount you can charge at any one time.', 'Yes. Many cards only offer 1% cash-back reward on all purchases, so a business credit card offering 1.5% cash back on all eligible purchases is likely a solid deal. Though 2% cash-back cards abound and for some businesses higher categorical rewards may be more lucrative, a 1.5% cash-back rate is certainly respectable.', 'Getting a cash-back business credit card is similar to getting any other type of credit card. Once you’ve identified a card that fits your business’ spending habits, you can apply. A business credit isn’t limited to those who work full-time or have a steady established business. It’s possible to get a cash-back business card even if it’s just to use for part-time work, a freelance position or an occasional side gig.', '\xa0', 'Most business credit cards can be applied for online or in some cases over the phone or in-branch if it’s a bank-issued card. If you know how to apply for a personal credit card, the process is similar. You’ll have to provide some basic information including your business’ contact details, annual revenue, industry type and number of employees. You’ll also need your company’s employee identification number (EIN) if you have one and your Social Security number.', '\xa0', 'Be aware that when you apply for a business credit card, you’re personally guaranteeing that you’ll repay the debt, just like you would for a personal credit card. In other words, if your business goes belly-up, you’re still on the hook for any balance owed.', 'Forbes Advisor rates the The Blue Business® Plus Credit Card from American Express the best overall business credit card. For a full list of our overall best startup business credit cards, view our list.', 'Business credit is different from personal credit, though personal credit is often used to provide a personal guarantee when a business does not have established credit. Businesses build credit by maintaining healthy credit accounts with lenders that regularly report to business credit reporting agencies. Like with personal credit, paying bills on time is a big factor. To learn more, read our guide to building business credit.', 'A small handful of business credit cards do not require a personal guarantee. These cards likely require some other form of proof your business is a worthy borrower—collateral, strong income or other risk-reducing factors the lender may want to see will likely help your chances of approval. Secured business credit cards may also provide another option for those applying for business credit cards without the best credit.', "
                Robin Saks Frankel is a credit cards and personal finance writer for Forbes Advisor. Previously, she covered credit cards and related content at other national web publications including NerdWallet, Bankrate and HerMoney. She's been featured as a personal finance expert in outlets including CNBC, Business Insider, CBS Marketplace, and has appeared on or contributed to Fox News, CBS Radio, ABC Radio, NPR, International Business Times and NBC, ABC and CBS TV affiliates nationwide.  Follow her on Twitter at @robinsaks.            "]

You'll also get a long intro APR offer on purchases. However, there is no rewards program nor any welcome bonus, making this truly a "simple" card for those looking to hold a balance for a long period of time.', 'Up to 5X Reward Rate', '

							Excellent, Good							(700 - 749)						', 'A good overall spending card that allows you to hold a balance on new purchases with a low introductory APR, pay no annual fee, and still earn at least 1.5% cashback on all purchases', 'Not all 0% APR cards are created equally. To generate our list of top picks for 0% APR credit cards, Forbes Advisor reviewed dozens of 0% APR credit cards across a broad spectrum of issuers.', 'We weighed a number of factors including the length of a card’s 0% APR offer, any welcome bonuses and any credit card fees as part of ownership and/or ability to transfer a balance from another card. We also considered the usefulness of the card beyond the intro APR period including if it earned rewards on purchases.', 'It’s easy to see why the Wells Fargo Active Cash℠ Card can’t be beat. It earns an unlimited 2% cash rewards on purchases, putting it head-to-head with the other best flat-rate cash-back cards on the market. Plus, the card also comes with a solid 0% APR offer, making it our top pick in this category.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Intro APR Offer: Get a 0% intro APR for 15 months from account opening on purchases and qualifying balance transfers, then a 15.24% to 25.24% variable APR applies. Balance transfers made within 120 days qualify for the intro rate and fee of 3% then a fee of up to 5%, with a minimum of $5 applies.', 'Balance Transfer Fee: up to 5%; min: $5', 'Other Drawbacks and Benefits: Though light on additional benefits, the point of the card is not the perks. This card is best for those who don’t need the bells and whistles and just want to focus on cash back.', 'Read our full review of the Wells Fargo Active Cash℠ Card.', 'The Amex EveryDay® Credit Card* offers a respectable 2 Membership Rewards points per dollar at US supermarkets on up to $6,000 per year in purchases (then 1X), 2 points per dollar when using the card to book trips through American Express Travel and 1 point for every eligible dollar on everything else. Plus, use the card 20 or more times on purchases in a billing period and earn 20% extra points on those purchases. It’s also a no-annual-fee way to earn Membership Rewards, which are transferable to airline and hotel partners.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Intro APR Offer: Get a 0% intro APR on purchases for 15 months, then a standard APR of 13.24% - 24.24% variable .', 'Balance Transfer Fee: $0', 'Other Drawbacks and Benefits: The card comes with secondary car rental coverage and global assistance services, a nice set of features for a no-annual-fee card. But other cards may offer higher rewards both on grocery purchases and all other spending so this card may be best for someone to use as part of an overall rewards maximizing strategy.', 'Read our full review of the Amex EveryDay® Credit Card*.', 'Those who don’t like annual fees or extra gimmicks may be satisfied with the Capital One VentureOne Rewards Credit Card. Earning 5 miles per dollar on hotels and rental cars booked through Capital One Travel and 1.25 miles per dollar on every other purchase, the card gets additional major value from the myriad of extra benefits standard on most Capital One cards.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Intro APR Offer: Get a 0% intro APR on purchases and balance transfers for 15 months; 15.24% - 25.24% variable APR after that.', 'Balance Transfer Fee: 3%', 'Other Drawbacks and Benefits: Though not as rewarding as its beefier peer, the Capital One Venture Rewards Credit Card, for the casual rewards earner the appeal may lie in the card’s intro 0% APR offer, the lack of an annual fee and the ability to transfer miles to qualifying partner hotel and airline programs.', 'Read our full review of the Capital One VentureOne Rewards Credit Card.', 'The Wells Fargo Reflect℠ Card is handy for anyone looking to pay down debt or stretch payments on a new, large purchase. The main selling point of this card is the long introductory rate on both new purchases and eligible balance transfers.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Intro APR Offer: Get a 0% intro APR for 18 months from account opening on purchases and qualifying balance transfers. An intro APR extension of up to 3 months with on-time minimum payments during the intro and extension periods is available. A variable APR of 13.24% to 25.24% variable APR applies after that. Balance transfers made within 120 days qualify for the intro rate and fee of 3% then a balance transfer fee of up to 5%, min $5 applies.', 'Balance Transfer Fee: up to 5%; min: $5', 'Other Drawbacks and Benefits: There are no rewards on this card, limiting its appeal beyond the promo period. However, the card does include cell phone insurance. When you pay your wireless bill with the card you’ll have access to up to $600 in coverage per claim for stolen and damaged phones (subject to a $25 deductible). Two claims may be made per year.', 'Read our full review of the Wells Fargo Reflect℠ Card.', 'If you’re looking for one of the longest runways possible to pay off a big purchase or pay down existing debt, the U.S. Bank Visa® Platinum Card is one of the top options available. The extra-lengthy 0% intro APR on purchases and balance transfers is the main event and the biggest reason you should consider this card.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Intro APR Offer: Get a 0% intro APR on purchases and balance transfers for 20 billing cycles, followed by a variable APR of 14.74% - 24.74%. A balance transfer fee of either 3% or $5 applies, whichever is greater.', 'Balance Transfer Fee: Either 3% of the amount of each transfer or $5 minimum, whichever is greater', 'Other Drawbacks and Benefits: Although there are no rewards for spending on this card, if you pay your monthly cell phone bill with the card you’ll get insurance for your primary phone and any additional lines for damage or theft up to $600 with a $25 deductible for up to two claims ($1,200) per 12-month period.', 'Read our full review of the U.S. Bank Visa® Platinum Card.', 'If you have the tolerance to track changing quarterly categories, the Discover it® Cash Back card can earn generous rewards in areas most people are likely to find appealing. Past examples include supermarkets, gas stations and warehouse clubs. That gives this card staying power beyond the intro 0% offer on purchases and balance transfers.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Intro APR Offer: Get a 0% introductory APR for 15 months on purchases and eligible balance transfers. Then, a standard rate of 12.24% - 23.24% variable applies. A balance transfer fee of up to 5% of the amount transferred applies.', 'Balance Transfer Fee: 3% intro balance transfer fee, up to 5% fee on future balance transfers (see terms)*', 'Other Drawbacks and Benefits: If you typically spend above and beyond the quarterly maximums, another card might yield better returns. The cash back match at the end of the first year could be a lucrative bonus, but it’s only a one-time reward.', 'Read our full review of the Discover it® Cash Back.', 'The Discover it® chrome was designed for consumers whose biggest areas of spending are gas stations and restaurants and can make good use of the 0% intro offer on purchases and balance transfers.', 'Discover cards all offer their own twist on a welcome bonus as well: You’ll automatically get an unlimited dollar-for-dollar match of all the cash back you earned at the end of your first year as a cardholder. Depending on how much you spend, this can be much more valuable than a traditional welcome bonus.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Intro APR Offer: Get a 0% introductory APR for 15 months on purchases and eligible balance transfers. Then, a standard rate of 12.24% - 23.24% variable applies. A balance transfer fee of up to 5% of the amount transferred applies.', 'Balance Transfer Fee: 3% intro balance transfer fee, up to 5% fee on future balance transfers (see terms)*', 'Other Drawbacks and Benefits: If you typically spend more than $1,000 per quarter on gas and dining, the rewards structure of this card might be too limiting for you. The 1% earnings on all other purchases can be easily bested by other rewards cards.', 'Read our full review of the Discover it® chrome.', 'The Chase Freedom Flex℠ has the brawn to handle just about all of your credit card spending needs without an over-inflated price tag. The card has an annual fee of $0, yet comes with a pumped-up earnings structure that covers a wide swath of expenses plus a meaty rewards structure to boot.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Intro APR Offer: Get a 0% intro APR for 15 months from account opening on purchases and balance transfers, then a variable APR of 14.99 - 23.74% applies. Intro balance transfer fee of either $5 or 3% of the amount of each transfer, whichever is greater in the first 60 days, after that either $5 or 5% of the amount of each transfer, whichever is greater applies.', 'Balance Transfer Fee: Either $5 or 5% of the amount of each transfer, whichever is greater.', 'Other Drawbacks and Benefits: The card’s benefits give it staying power in your wallet long after the introductory offer. But other cards offer longer 0% APR periods, which may be more valuable to you in the short term.', 'Read our full review of the Chase Freedom Flex℠.', 'The Citi Simplicity® Card aims to keep its introductory APR offer easy. The card charges no late fees, no penalty rate and no annual fee. It also doesn’t earn any rewards so it’s ideally best used as a tool in your debt payoff plan.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Intro APR Offer: Get a 0% intro APR for 21 months on balance transfers from date of first transfer, and 0% intro APR for 12 months on purchases from date of account opening. After that, the variable APR will be 14.99% - 24.99%, based on your creditworthiness. Balance transfers must be completed within 4 months of account opening. There is a balance transfer fee of either $5 or 5% of the amount of each transfer, whichever is greater.', 'Balance Transfer Fee: Balance transfer fee applies with this offer 5% of each balance transfer; $5 minimum', 'Other Drawbacks and Benefits: The Citi Simplicity® Card comes with Citi perks including the ability to choose your own due date and the ability to skip endless hold music by saying “representative.” But beyond the introductory period, there isn’t much incentive to use this card as it doesn’t earn rewards or offer other valuable benefits.', 'Read our full review of the Citi Simplicity® Card.', 'The Chase Freedom Unlimited® has powerful points-earning potential. This all-around workhorse of a card notches 5% cash back on travel purchased through Chase Ultimate Rewards®, 3% cash back on eligible dining and drugstores and 1.5% on all other purchases, all for an annual fee of $0.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Intro APR Offer: Get a 0% introductory APR for 15 months from account opening on purchases and balance transfers, then a variable APR of 14.99% - 23.74% applies.', 'Balance Transfer Fee: Either $5 or 5% of the amount of each transfer, whichever is greater.', 'Other Drawbacks and Benefits: Rewards earned on the card can be redeemed for straight cash back, travel, merchandise or pooled with another premium Chase Ultimate Rewards®-earning card for potential greater value when used for travel.', 'Read our full review of the Chase Freedom Unlimited®.', 'Purchase APR (Annual Percentage Rate) refers to the amount of interest you’ll pay on something you bought with your credit card if you carry a balance from month to month. Your card’s APR should be clearly spelled out when you’re approved for your card and also can be found on your monthly statement in the section showing how your interest for that billing cycle was calculated.', 'Most credit cards calculate interest using the average daily balance method, which means your interest is compounded and accumulates every day, based on your daily rate of interest. In other words, every day your finance charges are based on the balance from the day before. The daily rate of interest on your purchase is determined by dividing your card’s APR by 365 to find the daily rate of interest and then multiplying that number by your balance.', 'A 0% APR offer is an introductory period without finance charges on either purchases, balance transfers or both. Getting a break from finance charges can be a welcome change from the double-digit interest typically charged on credit cards or other loans. The less you’re paying in interest, the more you can put towards paying off your debt.', 'There’s no one best credit card with no interest, only what’s best for your particular circumstances. When choosing a credit card for its interest-free offer, if you’re seeking the best no interest offer on purchases, consider the length of time of the offer.', 'If you’re seeking the best no interest offer on a balance transfer card, consider both the length of time and the amount it will cost if there’s a balance transfer fee. You should also look beyond the interest-free period and see if there’s value to you in the card when the promotional offer expires.', 'An introductory APR is a promotional offer made by credit card companies to entice potential customers to sign up for a new card. An intro APR is typically either a 0% or ultra-low APR offer that applies for a limited period of time. When the intro offer expires the card will revert to its standard APR, which is within a range specified in the cardholder agreement.', 'A purchase interest charge is the amount you’ll pay in interest for anything you buy on your credit card. For example, if your credit card has an APR of 20% and you buy a new couch for $1,000, over the course of a year if you didn’t make a single payment towards your card, you’d tack on an additional $200 in interest charges.', 'In practice, you typically accrue interest on a daily accumulated rate, which means every day your finance charges are based on the balance from the day before. The daily rate of interest on your purchase is determined by dividing your card’s APR—in this example 20%— by 365 to find the daily rate of interest and then multiplying that number by your balance.', 'Since this method is compounding your interest charges, you’ll end up paying more than $200 in additional interest over the course of a year if you made zero payments towards that principal amount of your purchase.', "
                Robin Saks Frankel is a credit cards and personal finance writer for Forbes Advisor. Previously, she covered credit cards and related content at other national web publications including NerdWallet, Bankrate and HerMoney. She's been featured as a personal finance expert in outlets including CNBC, Business Insider, CBS Marketplace, and has appeared on or contributed to Fox News, CBS Radio, ABC Radio, NPR, International Business Times and NBC, ABC and CBS TV affiliates nationwide.  Follow her on Twitter at @robinsaks.            "]
