							Excellent							(750 - 850)						', 'Considering its lavish travel perks and the $325 annual travel credit, frequent travelers can easily justify the $400 annual fee. The U.S. Bank Altitude™ Reserve Visa Infinite® Card is only available to U.S. Bank customers.', 'Forbes Advisor considered airline, hotel and flexible reward credit cards both within their own categories and compared to other types cards. We rated cards based on their fees, rewards potential, value of rewards earned, ongoing benefits and more. The top airline, hotel and flexible rewards cards were chosen for this list.', 'The Capital One Venture X Rewards Credit Card changed the game in the travel rewards space and is not only our best travel card, it’s among the best cards on the market in any category. The points are easy to earn and simple to redeem, the card comes with a bevy of benefits and the credits can easily make the annual fee worthwhile. Just make sure you value using your rewards for travel.', 'Rewards: 2 miles per dollar on all eligible purchases and 5 miles per dollar on flights and 10 miles per dollar on hotels and rental cars when booking via Capital One Travel', 'Welcome Offer: 75,000 bonus miles after spending $4,000 on purchases within the first three months of account opening', 'Annual Fee: $395', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: That annual fee may seem scary, but the card comes with up to a $300 annual travel credit for bookings through the Capital One Portal and a 10,000 point anniversary bonus worth $100 in travel. While the credit does have to be used via the portal, it can be used on airfare, hotels or car rentals so should be fairly easy to redeem.', 'The card especially shines for families because it offers authorized user cards at no additional cost, which the other premium travel cards charge a pretty penny for. This gives every authorized user access to a Priority Pass membership. Even better, the Venture X gives top-tier Hertz President’s Circle status in addition to a large selection of travel coverages and benefits.', 'Venture Miles are easy to redeem as they can either be applied towards travel purchases or transferred to travel partners. The main downside to the Venture X is a lack of domestic transfer partners, meaning that points will take a bit more knowledge to redeem than American Express Membership Rewards and Chase Ultimate Rewards.', 'Read our Capital One Venture X Rewards Credit Card review to learn more.', 'As a general rule, if you’re looking for an airline-specific card, you’ll want to get a card with the airline you fly the most. In terms of the airline card that offers the best earnings potential, valuable points and additional useful benefits including lounge access, the United Club℠ Infinite Card comes out ahead.', 'Rewards: 4 miles per dollar on United® purchases, 2 miles per dollar on all other travel, on dining including eligible delivery services and 1 mile per dollar on all other purchases', 'Welcome Offer: 120,000 bonus miles after you spend $6,000 on purchases in the first 3 months from account opening', 'Annual Fee: $525', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The most prominent benefit of the United Club Card is access to United Club airport lounges and other Star Alliance Gold lounges. If you want access to United Clubs, this card is the most affordable way to get that access (yes, the annual fee is cheaper than paying for access directly). If this sounds like you, you’ll come out ahead right away. If you’re not at all interested in lounge access, this card isn’t likely to be the best choice.', 'If you are a regular United flyer, you’ll also benefit from two free checked bags for yourself and another person traveling on the same reservation, Premier Access, 25% back on in-flight purchases, expanded access to award flights and Premier Upgrades on award tickets if you have status.', 'The United Club℠ Infinite Card offers benefits not related to flying United, too. You’ll get up to $100 back to cover the application fee for Global Entry or TSA PreCheck. You’ll also receive the following travel insurance coverage: trip cancellation/interruption, trip delay, lost/damaged baggage, delayed baggage and primary auto rental collision damage. This card offers other protections including purchase protection, return protection and extended warranty coverage.', 'If you won’t benefit from lounge access, free checked bags and priority boarding—either because you already have status, because you don’t check bags or because you don’t fly a specific airline enough—you’ll benefit more from a flexible travel card like the Chase Sapphire Reserve or Chase Sapphire Preferred® Card.', 'Read our United Club℠ Infinite Card review to learn more.', 'In addition to earning points at a relatively quick rate, theHilton Honors Aspire Card from American Express* also offers complimentary top-tier Hilton Honors Diamond status. Hilton Diamond status will afford you benefits like complimentary breakfast at eligible restaurants, 100% bonus points on Hilton stays, lounge access when you enroll with priority pass and more when you stay at Hilton Hotels. The Aspire is the only hotel card that offers top-tier status just for holding the card.', 'Rewards: 14 Hilton Honors bonus points at participating hotels or resorts within the Hilton Portfolio, 7 points per dollar on eligible purchases for flights booked directly with airlines or American Express Travel, car rentals booked directly from select car rental companies and U.S. restaurants and 3 points per dollar on other eligible purchases', 'Welcome Offer: 150,000 Hilton Honors bonus points after spending $4,000 in purchases within the first 3 months of opening an account', 'Annual Fee: $450', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: While the Hilton Aspire card earns more points than some other cards on this list, keep in mind that hotel points are generally not as valuable as airline miles or flexible rewards points. That said, the Hilton Aspire Card is still a card that packs in the benefits.', 'Cardholders will receive a free night award that is valid for any Hilton property (availability required), but only on the weekend. You can earn an additional free night award after spending $60,000 on your card within a year. Cardholders also receive up to $250 in statement credits for purchases made at participating Hilton Resorts.
The Hilton Aspire card has quite a few non-Hilton-related travel benefits too. Cardholders will receive a complimentary Priority Pass Select airport lounge membership with enrollment, a $250 airline fee credit for incidental purchases at an eligible airline you select each year and secondary car rental loss and damage insurance. This card also offers return protection.', 'Read our Hilton Honors Aspire Card from American Express* review to learn more.', 'The Chase Sapphire Reserve® makes our list of best travel rewards cards for many reasons. While it does charge a high annual fee, it earns valuable rewards at a good rate, and offers a plethora of travel benefits including best-in-market travel insurance benefits. If you travel at least a couple times per year, this card deserves serious consideration.', 'Rewards: 5 points per dollar on air travel and 10 points per dollar on hotels and car rentals when purchasing travel through Chase Ultimate Rewards® immediately after the first $300 is spent on travel purchases annually. Earn 3 points per dollar on other travel and dining and 1 point per dollar spent on all other purchases', 'Welcome Offer: 50,000 bonus points after spending $4,000 on purchases in the first 3 months from account opening', 'Annual Fee: $550', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The Chase Sapphire Reserve is packed full of benefits. Ultimate Rewards points redeemed for travel through the Chase travel portal or the Pay Yourself Back feature are worth 1.5 cents each or points can be transferred at a 1:1 ratio to Chase’s travel partners. Partners include Hyatt and United where points can potentially be redeemed for even more value.', 'Cardholders can make up for a chunk of the annual fee with the $300 annual travel credit. This credit is applied automatically to your first $300 in travel purchases, and Chase has a broad definition of what counts as travel. Other benefits that are very likely to come in handy include a Priority Pass Select airport lounge membership with access to over 1,200 airport lounges worldwide once you enroll, and up to a $100 credit to cover your Global Entry or TSA PreCheck application fee.', 'Finally, you can rest assured when you travel because the Sapphire Reserve offers some of the best travel protections available on any credit card. You’ll get trip cancellation and interruption coverage, trip delay coverage, lost and damaged baggage coverage, delayed baggage coverage and primary car rental insurance coverage. This card also offers purchase protection, return protection and extended warranty benefits.', 'Read our Chase Sapphire Reserve® Review to learn more.', 'Travelers that love Hyatt love Hyatt. While the The World of Hyatt Credit Card isn’t necessarily the best way to earn Hyatt points, between the annual free night and the ability to spend towards status it is a good option for people who frequent Hyatt hotels.', 'Rewards: 9 points total per dollar spent at Hyatt - 4 bonus points per dollar spent at Hyatt hotels and 5 base points per dollar from Hyatt as a World of Hyatt member. Earn 2 bonus points per dollar spent at restaurants, on airline tickets purchased directly from the airlines, on local transit and commuting and on fitness club and gym memberships and 1 point per dollar on all other eligible purchases', 'Welcome Offer: 30,000 bonus points after spending $3,000 on purchases in the first 3 months from account opening. Plus, up to 30,000 more bonus points by earning 2 bonus points total per dollar spent in the first 6 months from account opening on purchases that normally earn 1 bonus point, on up to $15,000 spent', 'Annual Fee: $95', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: In addition to the ability to earn points in a wide range of categories, the World of Hyatt credit card offers cardholders a free hotel night valid at Category 1 to 4 Hyatt hotels and the ability to earn a second one after spending $15,000 on the card within a cardmembers anniversary year.', 'Depending on how much you spend on non-Hyatt travel purchases and at restaurants, the Chase Sapphire Reserve could offer you the ability to earn more Hyatt points in a year because Chase Ultimate Rewards points transfer to Hyatt at a 1:1 ratio.', 'Read our The World of Hyatt Credit Card review to learn more.', 'If you’re looking for the card that packs in the most Delta benefits, the Delta SkyMiles® Reserve American Express Card (Terms apply. See rates and fees) may be for you. Its most notable benefit is access to Delta SkyClub lounges when you travel on a Delta flight.', 'Rewards: 3 miles per dollar on Delta purchases and 1 mile per dollar on all other eligible purchases', 'Welcome Offer: 50,000 bonus miles and 10,000 Medallion® Qualification Miles (MQMs) after spending $3,000 in purchases in the first 3 months', 'Annual Fee: $550', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The Delta SkyMiles Reserve card is not a card to get for daily spending because it does not offer great earnings rates. If you’re interested in earning Delta SkyMiles, a better option is to get a card that earns American Express Membership Rewards points. Membership Rewards transfer at a 1:1 ratio to Delta.', 'However, if you’re looking for benefits when you fly Delta, this card is tough to beat. The most notable benefit is access to Delta SkyClubs when you fly same day with Delta, however, you’ll only receive two annual one-time passes to bring guests in with you. You’ll also have access to American Express’ exclusive Centurion Lounges when you book your Delta flight with your Delta Reserve card.', 'This card offers a couple of features that can help you on your way to earning Delta Medallion status. It offers the ability to earn 15,000 Medallion Qualification Miles (MQMs) when you spend $30,000 on your card, up to four times per calendar year. If you have status with Delta already, you’ll be put ahead of other members with the same status level as you on the upgrade priority list, and if you don’t have status you’ll still be eligible for upgrades after all other Medallion members.', 'Cardholders get their first checked bag on Delta flights for free, priority boarding and 20% back on in-flight Delta purchases when using their Reserve card. Other travel-related benefits offered by this card include up to a $100 credit to cover your Global Entry or TSA PreCheck application fee, trip delay and cancellation coverage* and secondary car rental insurance*. You also may benefit from extended warranty, purchase protection* and return protection*.', 'For more information check out our Delta SkyMiles® Reserve American Express Card review.', 'The BILT Mastercard* offers a unique opportunity to earn rewards on rent, but it has value to anyone seeking a card with valuable transfer partners with no annual fee. This new card is impressive enough to stand as a travel card on its own even if you don’t pay rent.', 'Rewards: 1 point per dollar on rent payments with no fees (on up to $50,000 in rent payments every year), 2 points per dollar on travel (when booked directly with an airline, hotel, car rental or cruise company), 3 points per dollar on dining and 1 points per dollar on all other purchases', 'Welcome Offer: This card does not offer welcome bonus.', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The Bilt Card is invite only, but it’s worth getting a spot on the waiting list. Bilt points are transferable to a number of valuable transfer partners including Hyatt and American Airlines. You can also save your points towards a down payment on a home if you decide travel takes a back bench to homeownership.', 'Read our BILT Mastercard* review to learn more.', 'Besides the baggage and boarding benefits you would expect from most airline cards, the United℠ Explorer Card opens up more opportunities when it comes to redeeming your miles. United opens up award space just for cardholders that you can take advantage of, giving a unique value to this card over other airline’s cards.', 'Rewards: 2 miles per dollar on dining including eligible delivery services, hotel stays and United® purchases and 1 mile per dollar on all other eligible purchases', 'Welcome Offer: 60,000 bonus miles after spending $3,000 on purchases in the first 3 months of account opening. Plus, earn an additional 10,000 miles after spending $6,000 total on purchases in the first 6 months of account opening', 'Annual Fee: $0 intro annual fee for the first year, then $95', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The United Explorer card offers travel protections including trip cancellation and interruption coverage, trip delay coverage, lost and damaged baggage coverage, car rental insurance coverage and up to $100 in credit toward your Global Entry or TSA PreCheck application fee.', 'Learn more about the United℠ Explorer Card in our review.', 'People who have significant expenses on travel or at restaurants and those who want to make their airport experience more comfortable with lounge access will do better with the Chase Sapphire Reserve®, but if you want to start earning Ultimate Rewards points and benefit from travel insurance without paying a high annual fee, this card is a good place to start.', 'Rewards: 5 points per dollar on travel purchased through Chase Ultimate Rewards®, 3 points per dollar on dining and 2 points per dollar on all other travel purchases and 1 point per dollar on all other purchases', 'Welcome Offer: 80,000 bonus points after spending $4,000 on purchases in the first 3 months from account opening', 'Annual Fee: $95', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: Chase Ultimate Rewards points can be redeemed through Chase’s travel portal, using the Pay Yourself Back option for 1.25 cents each or transferred to Chase’s airline and hotel transfer partners, like United and Hyatt, at a 1:1 ratio. The card also offers a $50 hotel credit when booked through the Ultimate Rewards portal and a 10% rebate on your spending in points each year. This means that if you spend $10,000 on the card, you’ll earn an additional 1,000 Ultimate Rewards points.', 'The Sapphire Preferred offers trip cancellation/interruption coverage, trip delay coverage, lost and damaged baggage coverage, bag delay coverage, and primary car rental insurance. It also offers purchase protection and extended warranty coverage.', 'Read our Chase Sapphire Preferred® Card review to learn more.', 'If you only stay in Hilton properties periodically but you still want Hilton benefits and more points on paid stays, consider the Hilton Honors American Express Surpass® Card*. This card offers fewer perks than the Hilton Honors Aspire Card from American Express* in exchange for a much lower annual fee, but you can still earn a generous welcome bonus and a surprising level of benefits.', 'Rewards: 12 Hilton Honors bonus points per dollar on eligible purchases at participating hotels or resorts within the Hilton portfolio, 6 points per dollar on eligible purchases at U.S. restaurants, at U.S. supermarkets, and at U.S. gas stations and 3 points per dollar for other eligible purchases', 'Welcome Offer: 130,000 Hilton Honors bonus points plus a Free Night Reward after spending $2,000 in purchases on the card in the first 3 months of card membership', 'Annual Fee: $95', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The Hilton Honors American Express Surpass® Card* is a toned-down version of the Aspire card with a lower annual fee and fewer benefits. The card does get you some perks including automatic Hilton Gold status, a weekend night award when you spend $15,000 on your card within a calendar year and no foreign transaction fees. Hilton Gold Status is good enough for most casual travelers as it offers a breakfast benefit at participating hotels in addition to upgrades and late checkout when available.', 'Interestingly, the Surpass card comes with 10 passes into Priority Pass airport lounges each year once enrolled. If you fly once or twice a year with a family, the value of a couple of lounge visits could easily offset the annual fee even without all of the other benefits.', 'Read our Hilton Honors American Express Surpass® Card* review to learn more.', 'Jetblue has two advantages for families over other airlines: it travels to destinations families tend to go to (coughFloridacough) and their TrueBlue program offers family pooling. The JetBlue Plus Card* also offers a checked bag benefit and bumped-up earnings on dining and groceries.', 'Rewards: 6 points per dollar on eligible JetBlue purchases, 2 points per dollar at restaurants and eligible grocery stores and 1 point per dollar on all other purchases', 'Welcome Offer: 60,000 bonus points after spending $1,000 on purchases and paying the annual fee in full, both within the first 90 days', 'Annual Fee: $99', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: If you regularly fly JetBlue, the Plus card is hard to beat. The card offers a 10 percent rebate on points redemptions and a 5,000 points anniversary bonus. You can also earn Mosaic status with $50,000 annual spending.', 'JetBlue recently partnered with American Airlines, but not all American destinations are currently bookable as JetBlue rewards. If you are looking for a card to get you to Europe or Asia, you might be better served with a full-service airline’s card.', 'Read our JetBlue Plus Card* review for more information.', 'The United Quest℠ Card is the Goldilocks United card: it’s a bit pricer than the Explorer card but not nearly as much as the Club Card. But with a $125 United purchase credit, two 5,000 MileagePlus credits earned annually after your first cardmember anniversary valid for eligible flight redemptions and two free checked bags when flying United, the Quest could be just right for you.', 'Rewards: 3 miles per dollar on United® purchases, 2 miles per dollar on dining, select streaming services and all other travel, plus 1 point per dollar on all other purchases', 'Welcome Bonus: 70,000 bonus miles after spending $4,000 on purchases in the first 3 months of account opening', 'Annual Fee: $250', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The Quest takes most of the Explorer card benefits, like expanded award inventory and a TSA PreCheck/Global Entry application fee credit and adds possible reward seat upgrades to the mix. Noticeably, the Quest does lack the two annual lounge passes that the Explorer offers.', 'You can also use the Quest card to earn 500 Premier qualifying points (PQP) for every $12,000 in net purchases (including purchases made by authorized users) up to a maximum of 3,000 PQP in a calendar year.', 'Read the United Quest℠ Card review to learn more.', 'Some cards offer bonuses on dining, some on groceries, but you can earn bonus points on basically anything you put in your mouth with the American Express® Gold Card (Terms apply. See rates and fees). If you travel occasionally but also want a card that offers accelerated points earning in more categories, the American Express® Gold Card is a viable option.', 'Rewards: 4 Membership Rewards® points per dollar at restaurants, plus takeout and delivery in the U.S., 4 Membership Rewards® points per dollar at U.S. supermarkets (on up to $25,000 per calendar year in purchases, then 1 point per dollar), 3 Membership Rewards® points per dollar on flights booked directly with airlines or through American Express travel and 1 point per dollar on other eligible purchases', 'Welcome Offer: 60,000 Membership Rewards® points after spending $4,000 on purchases in the first 6 months of card membership', 'Annual Fee: $250', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: Membership Rewards points can be redeemed for travel directly through American Express or they can be transferred at a 1:1 ratio to American Express’ partners, including Delta, Virgin Atlantic and Avios.', 'While this card doesn’t pack travel specific benefits, it does have a number of other notable benefits including up to $120 in annual dining credits if you enroll in the perk (valid at GrubHub, Seamless, The Cheesecake Factory, Ruth’s Chris Steakhouse, Boxed and participating Shake Shack locations—issued in $10 monthly statement credits).', 'If you’re looking for a card with solid travel benefits but a lower annual fee than the most premium cards, the American Express Gold Card may be a good fit.', 'Read our American Express® Gold Card review to learn more.', 'If you’re looking for lounge access but you’re not set on a specific airline’s lounges, The Platinum Card® from American Express (terms apply, see rates and fees) might be for you. You’ll get access to three different lounge programs with this card, in addition to a bunch of other travel benefits. The downside is the largest annual fee on our list.', 'Rewards: 5 membership rewards points per dollar for flights booked directly with airlines or with American Express Travel on up to $500,000 per calendar year, 5 points per dollar on prepaid hotels booked with American Express Travel and 1 point per dollar on other eligible purchases', 'Welcome Offer: 100,000 membership rewards points after spending $6,000 on purchases on the card in the first 6 months of card membership', 'Annual Fee: $695', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The Platinum Card® from American Express offers up to $200 back per year in Uber Cash credits for rides or Uber Eats in the U.S. —$15 each month and a $20 bonus in December when you link your Platinum card to your Uber account.', 'The Amex Platinum has become a luxury coupon book of sorts and the benefits can easily offset the annual fee and then some, as long as you use them. Many of the perks are very specifically applied and many also require enrollment. Terms and conditions apply, so check your offer terms or the application for more details.', 'Examples include a

column1: 20 per month streaming credit on specific vendors
column2: up to $25 per month Equinox statement credit towards Equinox+ digital fitness app
column5: 'If you book hotels directly with either Hilton or Marriott
column6: you’ll benefit from Gold status with each program and complimentary membership in premium car rental programs when you enroll. Cardholders have access to the Fine Hotels & Resorts Program and Hotel Collection including an up to $200 annual statement credit for prepaid hotel nights booked through one of those two programs (with a minimum two-night stay requirement). This card also includes secondary car rental loss and damage insurance for eligible claims*.'
column8: Membership Rewards points are incredibly versatile. They can be transferred at a 1:1 ratio to over a dozen hotel and airline partners or they can be used to redeem for travel directly through American Express.'
column9: 'Read our The Platinum Card® from American Express review to learn more.'
column10: 'The U.S. Bank Altitude® Reserve Visa Infinite® Card* is the Minneapolis-based bank’s premium travel card offering robust rewards and perks for those who want to squeeze the most value out of their earnings and get some extras to boot. The key distinction for this card is the elevated earnings rate for mobile wallet purchases. Rewards earned on this card can be redeemed at 50% more value when used for eligible travel.'
column11: 'Rewards: 5 points per dollar on prepaid hotels and car rentals booked directly in the Altitude Rewards\xa0Center
column12: 3 points per dollar on eligible travel purchases and mobile wallet\xa0spending and 1 point per dollar on all other eligible net purchases'
column14: 000 points worth $750 on travel after spending $4
column15: 500 in the first 90 days of account opening'
column17: 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The card is only available to applicants who already have an existing U.S. Bank relationship. For the premium price
column19: airport lounge access and is saddled with a minimum redemption amount requirement for hotels and rental cars. It does
column21: come with an annual travel and dining redemption credit of up to $325
column22: which could take some of the sting out of the cost of ownership.'
column23: 'Read our full review of the U.S. Bank Altitude® Reserve Visa Infinite® Card*.'
column24: 'A travel credit card is a card that earns rewards on travel. Those rewards come in a variety of ways. A travel card can earn airline miles
column25: hotel points or flexible points that can be redeemed either with transfer partners or applied towards travel charges.'
column26: 'A travel rewards credit card accrues miles or points for each purchase made with the card. Often
column27: these cards have an enticing welcome bonus that typically requires spending a certain amount of money within a specific time period after opening the card. After earning miles or points
column28: there are usually a few redemption options including redeeming for airline tickets
column29: gift cards or statement credits. As a general rule
column30: redeeming miles and points for travel will result in the most value.'
column32: like Chase Ultimate Rewards or American Express Membership Rewards
column33: are earned for each purchase made with the card. Every card has a different earning structure
column34: so one card may earn high rewards on travel and dining purchases while another may earn more points on groceries and gas spending. Often credit card points will have multiple redemption options
column36: travel or gift cards vs. a co-branded card which tends to earn rewards that can only be redeemed for one thing
column37: like travel with a specific airline or hotel or merchandise.'
column38: 'Airline and hotel point values often are variable
column39: which means that the worth of a point may fluctuate depending on the specific redemption. Some programs will tie the value of their points or miles to the cash equivalent of a ticket or hotel night
column40: others have a tiered system based on something like peak or off-peak travel times
column41: seat class or hotel category—or a combination of the two.'
column42: 'Since airline and hotel rewards are primarily redeemed towards nights or flights
column43: it makes sense to do the research before cashing in a stash of points to make the most of your redemption. Forbes Advisor’s Complete Guide to Redeeming Points and Miles is a good place to start.'
column44: 'Not all travel credit cards are alike. Here’s how the various types break down so you can choose which type of travel rewards card is best for your unique circumstances.'
column45: 'These types of credit cards earn rewards that can be transferred to other programs
column46: like airline or hotel loyalty programs. Transferable rewards include Chase Ultimate Rewards
column47: American Express Membership Rewards and Citi ThankYou Points.'
column48: 'Airline credit cards earn miles that can be used to redeem for future purchases with that airline. You can also use that airline’s miles to book flights on other carriers within the same airline alliance
column49: which may yield greater value for your earnings.'
column50: 'Many airline credit cards offer perks beyond earning miles. Usually the higher the annual fee
column51: the more benefits you’ll get. Some common airline credit card extras may include free checked baggage
column53: a TSA PreCheck/Global Entry application fee credit and airport lounge access. If you’re able to max out these extras
column54: the perks can often be worth more than the annual fee.'
column55: 'Anyone who stays in hotels at least semi-regularly and who can pledge loyalty to one hotel brand may find that a hotel credit card is right for them. With hotel credit cards
column56: you’ll earn rewards in the hotel’s currency
column58: Hilton Honors points or World of Hyatt points
column59: which are redeemable towards any eligible hotel property under that brand’s umbrella.'
column60: 'Owning a hotel credit card can be a much faster path towards accruing points than earning them on stays alone. Some cards confer automatic elite status upon ownership
column61: which comes with its own set of benefits that can range from late check-out to free breakfast to room upgrades. Some cards will also offer one night free annually every year you renew your card membership as well as other perks such as airport lounge access.'
column62: 'Credit card points may often have a fixed-value when redeemed for things like cash or travel where the issuer publishes the cash value per point. For example
column63: a card may offer a value of a penny per point when redeemed for any valid travel purchase.'
column65: fixed-value points currencies can also vary by redemption type. For example
column66: points on a card might be worth 1.5 cents each when redeemed for travel rewards
column67: but only be worth 1 cent each when redeemed for cash back.'
column68: 'If you’re traveling for work and you want to keep your business expenses separate from personal
column69: a travel business credit card may be worth considering. Business credit cards for travel function the same as consumer credit cards for travel
column70: although the business versions often offer different earnings rates and perks as well as a different annual fee structure.'
column71: 'If you aren’t sure if you should choose a travel credit card or a cash back credit card
column72: it makes sense to examine your goals. If you’re hoping to earn rewards to use towards future travel and/or want some perks to make your journey more comfortable
column73: a travel credit card might fit the bill. But
column74: if you want flexibility in how you use your credit card earnings
column75: cash offers the widest array of options since you can spend your money any way you’d like.'
column76: 'A co-branded card generally makes sense if you tend to stay loyal to that brand when you travel. Using a co-branded card can fast-track you towards elite status with a hotel or airline and often comes with other valuable benefits. If you’d prefer to fly any airline you choose and stay at any hotel brand you’d like
column77: a general travel card is likely a better choice for your needs.'
column79: the level of benefits will most likely be associated with the annual fee. A premium card might come with airport lounge access
column80: travel protections including trip cancellation and delay insurance and exclusive privileges at luxury hotels. A mid-range card might still offer auto rental insurance and a Global Entry/TSA Precheck benefit. Even a card with no annual fee might offer some basic benefits depending on the card.'
column81: 'A co-branded travel card will offer benefits specific to that brand. For airlines
column82: you might see a checked bag benefit or a rebate on in-flight purchases. For hotels
column83: you might see a status level
column84: a free annual night award or anniversary points. Both types of cards might offer you the ability to spend towards higher levels of status.'
column87: 'The best way to maximize your rewards is to use a credit card that aligns with your spending patterns. In other words
column88: if a large part of your budget goes towards travel and dining
column89: using a card that offers high rewards in those areas will make the most sense. Another option is to pair credit cards and use different cards in different areas of spending.'
column90: 'Understanding how to get the most out of the points and miles you earn from your travel credit card goes hand-in-hand with using the loyalty programs offered by most airlines and hotel brands. It’s free to join and you can belong to as many loyalty programs as you like. Typically when you sign up for a co-branded credit card affiliated with a particular brand
column91: you’ll automatically become a member of the loyalty program if you aren’t already.'
column92: 'Tracking your spending allows you to make sure that every time you make a purchase
column93: you’re using the card that will earn you the most rewards. This means knowing which card to use in which scenario based on how a particular merchant codes the purchase.'
column94: 'For example if you own two credit cards
column95: one that earns high rewards on dining and one co-branded airline
column96: it might not make sense to use the airline card to pay your restaurant tab since the dining card likely earns more rewards. You can do this by various methods as complicated as creating a spreadsheet or as simple as putting stickers on each card to remind you when to use it.'
column98: there are strategies to get the most value when it comes time to redeem your rewards too. When it comes time to cash in your travel rewards
column99: there’s generally two ways to do it. You can plan the itinerary you want
column100: and use your rewards to fully or partially off-set the cost. Or
column101: you can research to see where the rewards you have can be used to get the most bang for your buck. It comes down to how much work you’re comfortable doing.'
column102: 'Big bonuses on credit cards look like they’re here to stay. We saw generous offers throughout 2021 and several of the best credit cards in 2022 continue to offer welcome bonuses of 100
column103: 000 points or more. While those rewards can often be redeemed in several different ways
column104: travel still reigns supreme: a recent survey showed 29% of respondents would prefer to cash out for free flights or upgrades and another 25% prefer to redeem points for hotel stays.'
column105: 'If visions of luxury vacations are enticing you to apply for your next card
column106: be sure to consider what travel points are worth before blindly applying. Our survey showed that 42% of respondents expected travel points to be worth 20 cents or more each. Unless very strategically redeemed
column107: most customers don’t see redemption values that high. Receiving between 0.5 and 2.5 cents per point is more common and should be factored in when evaluating cards.'
column108: 'Once you do have a stash of rewards available—either from new cards or old standbys—be sure to use them. Smartly
column109: 72% of survey respondents are using their rewards to help cover the cost of one or more vacations this year (with 12% hoping to fund
column111: at least three trips). Travel is far from the only valid redemption option
column112: so if a trip isn’t in your immediate future
column113: look into other options instead of joining the 4% of respondents hoarding 100
column116: 000 U.S. adults was commissioned by Forbes Advisor and conducted by market research company OnePoll
column117: in accordance with the Market Research Society’s code of conduct. Data was collected between Feb. 4 and Feb. 7
column118: 2022. The margin of error is +/- 2.2 points with 95% confidence. This survey was overseen by the OnePoll research team
column119: which is a member of the MRS and has corporate membership with the American Association for Public Opinion Research (AAPOR). For a complete survey methodology
column120: including geographic and demographic sample sizes
column122: 'To view rates and fees for Delta SkyMiles® Reserve American Express Card please visit this page.'
column123: 'To view rates and fees for The Platinum Card® from American Express please visit this page.'
column124: 'To view rates and fees for American Express® Gold Card please visit this page.'
column125: 'Forbes Advisor’s best credit cards for travel insurance list has a variety of cards offering solid travel insurance. Although you shouldn’t get a credit for this feature alone
column126: it can be a useful money-saving extra. Credit cards that offer travel insurance tend to have high annual fees
column127: so keep this in mind when weighing whether or not you are likely to use the feature.'
column128: 'There’s no one “best” credit card when it comes to travel rewards—or any type of rewards for that matter. That’s because everyone’s spending patterns are different and someone who travels frequently will fare best with a different travel rewards card than someone who travels maybe once a year.'
column129: 'Many credit cards are well suited for international travel. You want to make sure that the card has no foreign transaction fees. It also helps if the card’s points are suitable for the locations where you wish to travel. For instance
column130: if you want to go to Asia
column131: an airline card co-branded with a U.S.-based airline that doesn’t fly to Asia
column134: 'The number of miles you need for a free flight depends on different factors including which airline miles you are using
column135: where you are flying to and from
column136: when you are traveling and other factors. Domestic flights in the U.S. will generally require fewer miles than an international flight. Typically
column139: 000 miles for a domestic one-way flight in economy.'
column140: 'Long-haul international flights can cost quite a bit more. Plan on spending between 20
column142: 000 miles each way to fly to Europe and even more for flights to Asia
column145: 'Don’t forget to consider the cost of checked bags and fuel surcharges before booking your ticket. Flights booked with rewards are also often subject to government taxes and fees.'
column146: 'Point values are as varied as the types of points themselves. Some cards’ points values are more straightforward because some points rates are somewhat tied to the cash prices. However
column147: if a program uses an awards chart the value of the point will vary widely depending on how you are redeeming it. In general
column148: you’ll get the highest value per point on premium airline seats and luxury hotel stays.'
column149: 'A travel rewards credit card will typically recommend good to excellent credit in order to qualify. Plan to have a credit score of at least 700 to get approved by the top credit cards on the market. Some of the top travel cards on the market might even require applicants to have a credit score of 720 or higher.'
column150: 'Points and miles are effectively the same
column151: they’re just different names for the rewards earned on a particular credit card. Some credit cards offer points
column152: some—particularly airline cards—offer miles. But the fundamental function is the same in that these rewards cards all earn a specified type of award currency based on your spending that can be used in various ways.'
column154: ""\n                Caroline Lupini is the Credit Card and Travel Analyst for Forbes Advisor. She's a credit card enthusiast and digital nomad who has leveraged credit cards to travel around the world for next to nothing
column155: often in style. Prior to working for Forbes
column156: she contributed to other leading publications in the credit cards and rewards space. She would like to visit every country and try as many different local culinary specialties as possible.            ""]"

							Excellent/Good							(700 - 749)						', "Delta's highest-tier premium rewards card is destined for high-flying business owners with the means to leverage the lavish perks. The Delta Sky Club® and annual companion ticket (for eligible flights, taxes and fees apply) alone are worth far more than the annual fee.", 'The Blue Business® Plus Credit Card from American Express (Terms apply. See rates and fees.) is interesting because you can earn Membership Rewards points without paying an annual fee. The card also offers an introductory APR offer, which allows a new business to acquire inventory or pay upfront expenses with time to pay them off without interest.', 'Rewards: 2 Membership Rewards points per dollar on everyday business purchases such as office supplies or client dinners up to the first $50,000 in purchases per year, then 1 point per dollar on all other purchases', 'Welcome Offer: 15,000\xa0Membership Rewards® points after spending\xa0$3,000 in eligible purchases on the card within the first\xa03 months of card membership', 'Annual Fee: No annual fee', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: This card offers 0% intro APR on purchases for 12 months from the date of account opening, then a variable rate of 13.49% - 21.49%. Balance transfers must be completed within 60 days of account opening and a fee of $5 or 3%, whichever is greater applies. This can be enticing if you want to save money on interest with a lower APR, but carrying a balance isn’t going to be a good idea in the long-run when the introductory period is over.', 'We do like the fact you can earn extra Membership Rewards® points per dollar on everyday business purchases such as office supplies or client dinners. However, if your business regularly spends more than $50,000 per year, a card without a cap may be a better choice. If you want a similar card but with cash back, consider the American Express Blue Business Cash™ Card.', 'Read our The Blue Business® Plus Credit Card from American Express review to learn more.', 'The World of Hyatt Business Credit Card earns top marks on our business hotel card rankings due to its combination of valuable perks and attractive earnings rates. This card makes it easy to earn rewards faster on paid Hyatt stays and on everything else you buy.', "Rewards: 4 points per dollar at Hyatt hotels, 2 points per dollar spent in a cardholder's top three spend categories each quarter through 12/31/22, then the top two categories each quarter, 2 points per dollar spent on fitness club and gym memberships and 1 point per dollar spent on all other purchases", 'Welcome Offer: 60,000 Bonus Points after you spend $5,000 on purchases in your first 3 months from account opening.', 'Annual Fee: $199', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The World of Hyatt Business Credit Card makes it easy to earn rewards that can be used for hotel stays in this program. The card offers a $100 rebate (redeemable as $50, twice a year) on Hyatt purchases and an incentive for spending $50,000 annually on the card: 10% of redeemed points back for the remainder of the year (up to 20,000 bonus points).', 'The downside of Hyatt is it’s lack of reach into many smaller markets and large sections of the globe. There are many places where a Hyatt portfolio hotel is nowhere to be found.', 'Check out our World of Hyatt Business Credit Card to learn more.', 'The United Club℠ Business card* is a brother to the personal United Club Infinite Card, with a slightly different earning structure. The high annual fee plus the other United perks would easily outweigh the annual fee if you would normally pay for a United Club membership anyway. If your business is not near a United hub, this card may not be for you.', 'Rewards: 2 miles per $1 spent on purchases from United, including tickets, Economy Plus®, inflight food, beverages and Wi-Fi, and other United charges; Earn 2 miles per $1 spent on Inside Access from Chase purchases; Earn 1.5 miles per $1 spent on all other purchases', 'Welcome Offer: 100,000 bonus miles after spending $10,000 on purchases in the first 3 months of account is open. Offer ends 5/4/2022', 'Annual Fee: $450', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The United Club℠ Business card* has pumped-up benefits, but charges a steep annual fee. Besides United Club membership, the Business Club card offers Premier Access at the airport, space-available upgrades on award tickets, your free first and second checked bags, 25% off in-flight purchases when you pay with your card and Avis President’s Club.', 'This card also comes with a suite of travel and purchase protections including trip cancellation and interruption insurance, trip delay coverage, lost and damaged baggage insurance, delayed baggage coverage, rental car insurance coverage, purchase protection, return protection and extended warranty.', 'Read our United Club℠ Business card* review to learn more.', 'The Chase Ink Business Unlimited® Credit Card is marketed as a cash-back card, and offers a relatively high rate of cash back. When paired with a premium Chase Ultimate Rewards-earning card like the Ink Business Preferred® Credit Card, Chase Sapphire Preferred® Card or Chase Sapphire Reserve®, earnings can be taken as Ultimate Rewards points which can make this card even more valuable. The Unlimited tops the Ink Preferred if you want a straightforward earnings rate rather than bonus categories as long as you pair it with a card that has transferable rewards.', 'Rewards: 1.5% cash back rewards on every business purchase', 'Welcome Offer: $750 bonus cash back after spending $7,500 on purchases in the first 3 months from account opening', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The “set it and forget it” rewards from the Chase Ink Unlimited couldn’t be easier to earn, making this a solid choice if you only want one business card but want to earn variable rewards. That said, you’ll need to pair it with another Ultimate Rewards-earning card with transferable points if you want to unlock the full potential of this card.
If you’re after the highest rate of cash back alone, it’s possible that another card would provide more value.', 'Read our Ink Business Unlimited® Credit Card review to learn more.', 'Those who routinely make purchases of $5,000 or more may find the rewards potential on the Chase Ink Business Premier* hard to beat. You’ll also earn big rewards for travel booked through the Chase Ultimate Rewards travel center too.', 'Rewards: 5% cash back on travel purchased through Chase Ultimate Rewards®, 2.5% cash back on every purchase of $5,000 or more, and 2% cash back on every other purchase.', 'Welcome Offer: $1,000 cash back after spending $10,000 on purchases in the first 3 months from account opening.', 'Annual Fee: $195', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The card offers bountiful flat-rate rewards, especially for big spenders. But those who want to maximize their redemption values by combining the earnings on this card with another premium Chase Ultimate Rewards card are out of luck. You cannot transfer rewards from this card to another.', 'One of the rare business cards that doesn’t require a personal guarantee, the Brex 30 Card is an option if you have significant assets. If you have a minimum of $50,000 to $100,000 available in liquid capital the card could be a good fit.', 'Rewards: 8 points per dollar on rideshare, 5 points per dollar on travel booked through Brex Travel, 4 points per dollar on restaurants, 3 points per dollar on recurring software and 1 point per dollar on everything else', 'Welcome Offer: 30,000 points after spending $3,500, or 50,000 points after spending $9,000 within 30 days', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The Brex 30 Card does not require a personal guarantee, security deposit or credit check to apply if you have significant enough assets. Just remember that it’s a charge card rather than a credit card, meaning that the balance is due in full and on time each billing cycle.', 'Check out our Brex 30 Card review to learn more.', 'The Ink Business Preferred® Credit Card offers the ability to earn valuable Chase Ultimate Rewards points at compelling rates and an impressive bonus offer, making it a top pick for business travel. Ultimate Rewards are valuable because they are so flexible. You can redeem directly for travel at 1.25 cents per point through Chase or transfer to over a dozen loyalty programs including United, Southwest and Hyatt.', 'Rewards: 3 points per dollar on the first $150,000 spent on travel and select business categories each account anniversary year and 1 point per dollar on all other purchases', 'Welcome Offer: 100,000 points after you spend $15,000 on purchases in the first 3 months from account opening', 'Annual Fee: $95', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The “select business categories” include shipping, internet, cable and phone, and social media and search engine advertising. If your business does a lot of online advertising, this card will rake in the rewards.', 'Ultimate Rewards from the Chase Ink Preferred can be combined with personal Ultimate Rewards points to help grow balances quickly.', 'This card also offers cell phone insurance limited to three claims of up to $600 each per year, subject to a $25 deductible. This card also offers trip cancellation and interruption insurance, primary auto rental insurance when you rent for business purposes (secondary if you’re renting for personal reasons), purchase protection and extended warranty coverage.', 'Read our review of the Ink Business Preferred® Credit Card to learn more.', 'The Wells Fargo Business Elite Signature Card* was created with big spenders in mind and can provide up to 200 employee cards with each account. Best of all, the 7.49% variable APR on purchases is worthy of a second look if you need to carry a balance past an introductory period.', 'Rewards: 1.5% cash back per dollar spent or earn 1 point per dollar spent and receive 5,000 bonus points when the company spend is $10,000 or more in any monthly billing period', 'Welcome Offer: $1,000 one-time cash back bonus or 100,000 bonus points after spending $15,000 in the first three months of account open date', 'Annual Fee: $125 annual fee (waived first year)', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The Wells Fargo Business Elite Signature Card* charges an annual fee of $125 annual fee (waived first year) but the rewards and interest rate savings a cardholder can gain might be well worth it.', 'Keep in mind that the minimum spending threshold for the bonus offer is $25,000 within three months. If your business doesn’t spend $8,334 on average on a monthly basis, you may want to consider a business credit card with an easier-to-earn bonus.', 'If you want a no annual fee card that allows you to earn valuable rewards, Ink Business Cash® Credit Card is a good option. This card is marketed as a cash back card, but can be paired with a premium Chase Ultimate Rewards-earning card to unlock the full value of Chase Ultimate Rewards points. The card also offers protections that you don’t often see on a no-annual-fee card including primary car rental insurance for your business and purchase protection.', 'Rewards: 5% cash back on the first $25,000 spent in combined purchases at office supply stores and on internet, cable and phone services each account anniversary year and 2% cash back on the first $25,000 spent in combined purchases at gas stations and restaurants each account anniversary year. Earn 1% cash back on all other purchases', 'Welcome Offer: $750 bonus cash back after spending $7,500 on purchases in the first 3 months from account opening', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The higher rewards rates have an annual limit which may not be ideal for some businesses. While the card is marketed as a cash back card, it actually earns Ultimate Rewards. Ultimate Rewards from the Ink Business Cash® Credit Card must be combined with personal Chase Sapphire Preferred® Card or Chase Sapphire Reserve® points in order to utilize airline partner transfers where they can be worth more than 1 cent each.', 'If you’re just looking for one card, the Ink Business Cash Card could still be a good option if you regularly spend in the bonus categories but don’t think you’ll exceed the annual cap. If that doesn’t sound like you, you should look elsewhere.', 'Read our Ink Business Cash® Credit Card review to learn more.', 'The Amazon Business Prime American Express Card* offers the unusual ability to either earn rewards or enjoy an extended repayment period of up to 90 days on select Amazon purchases up to $120,000 per year. You can change your preference as often as you wish in order to maximize your rewards and/or interest savings.', 'Rewards: 5% back in rewards or 90 Days Terms on eligible U.S. purchases at Amazon Business, AWS, Amazon.com and Whole Foods Market with an eligible Prime membership. The 5% reward rate applies to the first $120,000 in purchases each calendar year. Earn 2% at U.S. restaurants, U.S. gas stations, and on wireless telephone services purchased directly from U.S. service providers and 1% on other purchases', 'Welcome Offer: Amazon.com gift card upon approval for the Amazon Business Prime American Express Card
', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: An Amazon Business Prime membership is needed to hold this card. Prices for a Business Prime membership start at $69 a year for one user up to $10,999 a year for an enterprise membership. Be sure to do the math to make sure the Prime membership works for you.', 'Check out our Amazon Business Prime American Express Card* review to learn more.', 'The American Express Blue Business Cash™ Card (Terms apply, see rates and fees) is a set and forget business credit card that lets you earn rewards without an annual fee. Consider this card if you want to earn without worrying about categories and you typically spend $50,000 or less a year.', 'Rewards: 2% cash back on all eligible purchases on up to $50,000 per calendar year, then 1%', 'Welcome Offer: Earn a\xa0$250\xa0statement credit after you make\xa0$3,000 in purchases\xa0on your Card in your first\xa03\xa0months', 'Annual Fee: No annual fee', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: A business that routinely spends more than $50,000 in a year would fare better with a card that doesn’t cap earnings rates. If you want a similar card but with more flexible rewards than cash, consider the The Blue Business® Plus Credit Card from American Express which is this card’s Membership Rewards-earning sibling.', 'Check out our American Express Blue Business Cash™ Card review to learn more.', 'The U.S. Bank Business Triple Cash Rewards World Elite™ Mastercard® is one of few cards offering a balance transfer promotional rate: 0% introductory APR on purchase and balance transfers for 15 billing cycles, followed by a regular variable APR of 14.24% - 23.24%. Making the card even more appealing are both rewards earning and welcome offer opportunities.', 'Rewards: 3% cash back on eligible purchases at gas stations, office supply stores, cell phone service providers and restaurants and 1% cash back on all other eligible net purchases', "Welcome Offer: Earn $500 in cash back. Just spend $4500 on the Account Owner's card in the first 150 days of opening your account.", 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The U.S. Bank Business Triple Cash Rewards World Elite™ Mastercard® offers a 0% introductory APR on purchase and balance transfers for 15 billing cycles, followed by a regular variable APR of 14.24% - 23.24%, adding to more possible savings. With free employee cards and an annual software credit, this card could be worth holding onto even after the APR period expires.', 'Check out our U.S. Bank Business Triple Cash Rewards World Elite™ Mastercard® review to learn more.', 'If your business expenses vary from month to month, look to a card like the U.S. Bank Business Leverage® Visa Signature® Card*, which offers elevated rewards in your top two spending categories, from a whopping 48 choices, meaning many types of expenses will qualify. With no effort on your part, you’ll earn more on what you spend each month.', 'Rewards: 2 points per dollar on eligible net purchases made in the top two categories where the most is spent each month and 1 point per dollar on all other eligible net purchases', "Welcome Offer: Earn 75,000 points worth $750 cash back by spending $7,500 in eligible net purchases on the account owner's card within the first four months of account opening.", 'Annual Fee: $0 intro annual fee, then $95', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: There’s no need to opt-in to bonus categories or track where you’re spending the most since the card will automatically adjust to how you spend. If your business uses U.S. Bank to process credit card payments from your customers you can earn additional points from those transactions. However, if you consistently spend heavily in more than two categories, you’ll likely fare better with a flat-rate rewards card.', 'Check out our U.S. Bank Business Leverage® Visa Signature® Card* review to learn more.', 'We aren’t highlighting the bank in many of our reviews, but the Bank of America’s Preferred Rewards program gives the Bank of America® Business Advantage Customized Cash Rewards Mastercard® credit card a leg up if you live in their ecosystem. With no annual fee and elevated earnings in your choice out of six categories, the card earns elevated cash back for up to $50,000 in combined eligible category spending per year.', "Rewards: 3% cash back in the category of your choice, 2% cash back on dining purchases and unlimited 1% cash back on all other purchases. You'll earn 3% and 2% cash back on the first $50,000 in combined choice category/dining purchases each calendar year and 1% thereafter", 'Welcome Offer: Get a $300 statement credit online bonus after you make at least $3,000 in net purchases within 90 days of your account opening ', 'Annual Fee: $0', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The card offers solid earnings for most business owners, but becomes best in class for those who qualify for the top tier of the Preferred Rewards program. Depending on the total amount a Preferred Rewards Member has in their qualifying accounts, they can earn 25% to 75% more rewards for each dollar they spend on their Bank of America rewards cards.', 'Check out our Bank of America® Business Advantage Customized Cash Rewards Mastercard® credit card review to learn more.', 'The American Express® Business Gold Card (Terms apply. See rates and fees.) is a solid option for business owners who want to maximize their earnings but don’t want to put a lot of thought into it. American Express automatically rewards you at a generous rate on your top two categories of spending from a selected list, chosen automatically each month in the areas you spend the most. Many cards offer quarterly or rotating bonus categories, but the American Express Business Gold Card does the work for you.', 'Rewards: 4 Membership Rewards® points per dollar on the 2 select categories where a business spends the most each month. 1 point per dollar is earned for other purchases.  The 4 point per dollar earning rate applies to the first $150,000 in combined purchases from the 2 eligible categories each calendar year', 'Welcome Offer: 70,000 Membership Rewards® points after spending $10,000 on eligible purchases within the first 3 months of opening an account', 'Annual Fee: $295', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: A notable travel perk the Amex Business Gold has is 25% of the points you use when you book eligible flights with American Express Travel back, up to 250,000 points back per calendar year. American Express also grants users travel and transportation protections, such as baggage insurance, emergency assistance and no foreign transaction fees.', 'Additionally, American Express has one of the most robust benefits programs out there with protections including purchase protection and extended warranty coverage. Cardholders have the ability to pay balances over time with interest, and there are no pre-set spending limits on the Business Gold card.', 'Read our American Express® Business Gold Card review to learn more.', 'The United℠ Business Card has benefits when flying United that outweigh its annual fee and some significant additional perks including a $100 flight credit with qualifying purchases.', 'Rewards: 2 miles per dollar on United purchases, on dining (including eligible delivery services), at gas stations, office supply stores, and on local transit and commuting and 1 mile per dollar on all other purchases', 'Welcome Offer: 75,000 bonus miles after spending $5,000 on purchases in the first 3 months of account opening', 'Annual Fee: $0 introductory annual fee for the first year, then $99', 'Other Benefits and Drawbacks: The United℠ Business Card offers two United Club passes, one free checked bag for the cardholder and a companion on the same reservation when you use your card to purchase your ticket and a 25% rebate on in-flight purchases. The Business Card goes a step further by offering a $100 travel credit after seven United purchases of $100 or more are made on the card each anniversary year.', 'Check out our United℠ Business Card review to learn more.', 'The Wyndham Rewards® Earner℠ Business Card* has unmatched earnings in categories that cater to those who live in their cars. With an industry-leading bonus on gas station purchases and healthy earning on Wyndham hotel stays, the card is a no-brainer if you are comfortable in the budget hotels that make up the vast majority of Wyndham’s portfolio and spend a lot of time on the road.', 'Rewards: 8 points per $1 spent on Hotels By Wyndham and gas purchases, 5 points per $1 spent on marketing, advertising and utilities and 1 point per $1 spent on all other purchases.', 'Welcome Offer: Earn 45,000 bonus points, enough for up to 6 free nights at participati

column68: 'With the many different types of credit cards available
column69: picking one for a business can be a lengthy process. Prospective cardholders have multiple factors to take into consideration before landing on a best-pick.'
column70: 'Annual fees often cover membership benefits offered by cards. Prospective cardholders should calculate how much they’ll need to spend in order to accumulate enough rewards or cash back to offset that fee.'
column71: 'Some cards have high points per dollar offers
column72: but when it comes to redeeming the points
column73: they fall flat. Be diligent in evaluating each point value and be sure you’re looking past the number of points in favor of what the points will actually get you.'
column74: 'Many cards will offer not only a welcome bonus
column75: but an intro APR. What amount of time will the card offer that teaser rate? Make sure you will be able to pay off any large purchases before the interest rate applies.'

column77: looking for a card with low interest rates
column79: can save money. Always remember that APRs are determined based on your creditworthiness
column80: so the lowest interest rate presented in the terms and conditions might not be what you’re granted upon approval.'
column81: 'Is the card a charge card or a credit card? A charge card will need to be paid off monthly
column82: while a credit card will allow you to carry a balance with interest. Make sure you know which type of card you are applying for and that it will best fit your needs.'
column83: 'When you’re ready to get a business card
column85: your income information and apply either online or at a bank branch.'
column87: and some cards will require a personal guarantee. This means an individual
column88: usually the one applying for the card on behalf of the company
column89: will be held liable for any balances left unpaid on the card. For individuals who don’t want to be tied to their business account
column90: there are cards available that don’t require a personal guarantee
column91: such as the Brex Visa Commercial Credit Card.'
column92: 'Most cards that let you apply online will let you know right away if you are approved. Occasionally the bank may want additional information before giving you a credit line but if it’s a “yes”
column93: you’ll usually learn when you apply.'
column94: 'A business credit card is a line of credit issued to a small business or sole proprietorship. They allow business owners to keep their business and personal expenses separate. By doing so
column97: 'Business credit cards operate just like a personal credit card
column98: with the exception that the card may have a different rewards structure or offer different protections.'
column99: 'The main way business credit cards differ from personal credit cards is in their lack of consumer protections like those in the CARD Act. Business credit cards may also report to business credit agencies and offer different rewards and benefits than personal credit cards.'
column100: 'You can access a free copy of your business credit score from Dun & Bradstreet’s CreditSignal program
column101: which provides access to some of your scores through a 14 day free trial or through Nav’s business credit reports which will give you a summary of your business scores from the three main business credit reporting agencies: Experian
column103: 'For full access to your business scores
column105: Dun & Bradstreet and Equifax all offer several different types of paid access to your business credit history from a basic score to comprehensive score improvement tips.'
column106: 'Whether it’s a full-fledged endeavor or a side hustle from your corporate job
column107: it’s still possible to get approved for a business credit card. That’s because business cards typically rely on your personal credit score as one of the determining factors for approval. If your FICO score isn’t as good as your business idea
column108: there’s a small handful of secured credit cards for businesses that can help you improve your credit while you build your brand.'
column109: 'Be aware that with nearly all small business cards
column110: just like with a personal credit card
column111: you are personally liable for any debts accrued to the card. In other words
column113: you’re still responsible for any debt left on the card.'
column114: 'Choosing the best business card for your particular circumstances will be based on a combination of your business spending patterns
column115: your goals in owning a particular business card (such as if you want rewards or a 0% introductory APR offer) and your personal credit history. There’s no one best card that can satisfy everyone’s needs.'
column117: which is generally a three-digit-figure determined by Experian
column119: business credit scores are calculated by Dun & Bradstreet
column120: Experian and Equifax on a scale of 1 to 100
column122: 'A business credit score differs from a personal credit score in both the scoring system used and their intended purpose. A business credit score is on a scale from 1 to 100
column123: with 100 being the highest possible score. A personal credit score is a three-digit number
column124: usually starting at 350 and going up to 850.'
column125: 'Just like having a strong personal credit score can qualify you for better rates on your loans
column126: a good business score can also signal to lenders that you’re qualified for financing on purchases or other loans. For example
column127: if you need to sign a lease on a bigger space for your business
column128: add a new truck to your fleet or make a big purchase of supplies for your business
column129: a potential lender will likely check your business credit score to determine your creditworthiness and what terms to grant you.'
column130: 'When you apply for a business credit card
column131: your approval will be based on your personal credit score. It also means you’ll be personally liable for any debts accrued on the card even if they’re from your business and that business fails. The issuer will also take other factors into consideration
column132: like your business income and credit history.'
column133: 'It’s possible to apply for a business credit card with an EIN but most small business credit card applications will also require your Social Security number. That’s because most small business cards require a personal guarantee as part of the cardmember agreement.'
column135: a corporate credit card will only require your company’s EIN because corporate cards are designed for bigger companies with lots of revenue. There are very few business cards that don’t require a personal guarantee. One notable exception is the Brex card
column136: which is designed for well-funded startups with at least $100
column139: when you apply for a business credit card
column140: your approval will be based on your personal credit score. It also means you’ll be personally liable for any debts accrued on the card even if they’re from your business and that business fails.'
column141: 'There are a small handful of business credit cards that don’t require a personal guarantee
column142: like the Brex Corporate Card for Startups or the Stripe Corporate Card
column143: that are aimed at well-funded corporations and require a review of your company’s financials to be considered. For small to mid-sized businesses
column144: you’ll have to agree to a personal guarantee in order to get a small business credit card.'
column145: 'Dun and Bradstreet is just one of the credit bureaus that have a business credit score matrix. Most major banks will report to the main credit bureaus including Dun and Bradstreet
column146: but it is always best to check directly with your bank if you have any questions.'
column147: '\n                Dia Adams is a noted family travel expert and a real-life Mom of two teens in the DC Metro area. She has visited over 45 countries and lived in Thailand
column149: and Ireland (where her son was born). Her kids have over 20 stamps in their own passports. Her passion lies in showing families how to travel more while keeping their savings and sanity.  Her guidebook
column152: ""\n                Robin Saks Frankel is a credit cards and personal finance writer for Forbes Advisor. Previously
column153: she covered credit cards and related content at other national web publications including NerdWallet
column154: Bankrate and HerMoney. She's been featured as a personal finance expert in outlets including CNBC
column157: and has appeared on or contributed to Fox News
column162: ABC and CBS TV affiliates nationwide.  Follow her on Twitter at @robinsaks.            ""]"

column6: ['You might be using an unsupported or outdated browser. To get the best possible experience please use the latest version of Chrome, Firefox, Safari, or Microsoft Edge to view this website.', 'Updated: Apr 14, 2022, 9:51am', 'Here are the average annual percentage rates (APR) today on 30-year, 15-year and 5/1 ARM mortgages:', '\n', 'The average APR for the benchmark 30-year fixed-rate mortgage fell to 5.14% today from 5.22% yesterday. This time last week, the 30-year fixed APR was 5.10%. Meanwhile, the average APR on the 15-year fixed mortgage is 4.39%. This same time last week, the 15-year fixed-rate mortgage APR was at 4.25%. Rates are quoted as APR.', 'The average APR on the 30-year fixed-rate jumbo mortgage is 5.02%. Last week, the average APR on a 30-year jumbo was 5.04%. The average APR on a 5/1 ARM is 4.49%. Last week, the average APR on a 5/1 ARM was 4.45%.', 'There are many ways to search for the best mortgage lenders, including through your own bank, a mortgage broker or shopping online. To help you with your search, here are some of the top mortgage lenders based on our list of this month’s best mortgage lenders.', 'Borrowers who comparison shop tend to get lower rates than borrowers who go with the first lender they find. You can compare rates online to get started. However, to get the most accurate quote, you can either go through a mortgage broker or apply for a mortgage through various lenders.', 'The advantage of going with a broker is you do less of the work and you’ll also get the benefit of their lender knowledge. For example, they might be able to match you with a lender who’s suited for your borrowing needs, this could be anything from a low down payment mortgage to a jumbo mortgage. However, depending on the broker, you might have to pay a fee.', 'Applying for a mortgage on your own is straightforward and most lenders offer online applications, so you don’t have to drive to an office or branch location. Additionally, applying for multiple mortgages in a short period of time won’t show up on your credit report as it’s usually counted as one query.', 'Finally, when you’re comparing rate quotes, be sure to look at the APR, not just the interest rate. The APR reflects the total cost of your loan on an annual basis.', '', 'A\xa0mortgage rate\xa0is the interest rate on a mortgage. It’s also known as the mortgage interest rate. The mortgage rate is the amount you’re charged for the money you borrowed. Part of every payment that you make goes toward interest that accrues between payments.', 'While interest expense is part of the cost built into a mortgage, this part of your payment is usually tax-deductible, unlike the principal portion.', 'Several economic factors influence rates, from inflation to monetary policy. Likewise, different lenders charge different mortgage rates for a variety of reasons, including varying operating costs, risk tolerance and even how much they want new business. Your personal financial information—including credit score, debt-to-income ratio and income history—also have a significant impact on interest rates.', 'Mortgage rates can change drastically and often—or stay the same for many weeks. The important thing for borrowers to know is the current average rate. You can check Forbes Advisor’s mortgage rate tables to get the latest information.', 'The lower the rate, the less you’ll pay on a mortgage. Today’s rate environment is considered extremely well-priced for borrowers. However, depending on\xa0your financial situation, the rate you’re offered might be higher than what lenders advertise or what you see on rate tables.', 'If you’re hoping to get the most competitive rate your lender offers, talk to them about what you can do to improve your chances of getting a better rate. This might entail\xa0improving your credit score, paying down debt or waiting a little longer to strengthen your financial profile.', 'The interest rate is the cost of borrowing money whereas the APR is the yearly cost of borrowing as well as the lender fees and other expenses associated with getting a mortgage.', 'The APR is the total cost of your loan, which is the best number to look at when you’re comparing rate quotes. Some lenders might offer a lower interest rate but their fees are higher than other lenders (with higher rates and lower fees), so you’ll want to compare APR, not just the interest rate. In some cases, the fees can be high enough to cancel out the savings of a low rate.', 'A mortgage rate lock allows you to lock in the interest rate your lender quotes you for a certain period of time. This gives you a chance to close on the loan without risking an increase in the mortgage interest rate before you finalize the loan process.', 'Once you find a rate you like, lock it in as soon as possible because rates can change overnight. If they rise, then you could end up paying more on your mortgage.', 'If you get a floating rate lock, then you can lock in a lower interest rate if rates fall, but you won’t be obligated to pay higher interest rates than you were quoted if they go up.', 'While 30-day rate locks are typically included in the cost of a mortgage, a floating rate lock could cost extra. Depending on how volatile the rate environment is, you might find that a floating lock is worthwhile.', 'For much of the population, buying a home means working with a\xa0mortgage lender\xa0to get a mortgage. It can be difficult to figure out how much you can afford and what you’re paying for.', 'Using a\xa0mortgage calculator\xa0can help you estimate your monthly mortgage payment based on your interest rate, purchase price, down payment and other expenses.', 'To calculate your monthly mortgage payment, here’s what you’ll need:', 'How much The\xa0house you can afford\xa0depends on a number of factors, including your income and debt.', 'Here are a few fundamental factors that go into what you can afford:', ' \n']

Eligible DreaMaker borrowers may also get $500 after completing a homebuying education course.', 'Chase also offers relationship discounts for eligible existing Chase customers in the form of reduced processing fees and lower rates. For example, customers who have combined assets in Chase deposit and investment accounts totaling between $150,000 and $499,999 will get $500 off the mortgage processing fee. Borrowers with $500,000 or more will get a $1,500 reduction from the processing fees. Chase also offers a rate discount of up to 0.25% if you have at least $1 million in deposits and investments there.', 'Available in Most States', 'Chase mortgages are offered in 48 states and Washington, D.C.; they are not available in Hawaii or Alaska.
